On Fri, Mar 15, 2013 at 2:09 PM, Eric Reed notifications@github.com wrote:

Been banging my head against this one all day and haven't figured out why
this is happening yet but I did discover something else I don't think we
should be doing...
When validating the library, we run through validation for not only the
physical root but also for each individual user. With the exception of the
user roots themselves, the user "libraries" are nothing but references back
to the physical library - which we just validated. Why are we traversing it
again for each user?

Luke Pulverenti
. It validates everything sequentially in order to avoid that. There's no
parallelizaton in that method.
If that code turns out to be nothing but redundant than I'll remove it, but
I can't think of any problems that that code would cause, other than wasted
cpu cycles. If it does cause a problem then we have some fragility
elsewhere that ought to be looked at.

as - even if we get the single instance thing worked out (which I think I
just have) - repeating this validation on each user is going to potentially
cause the same items to be validating simultaneously.

. If this eliminates three http requests per movie, then it's a change worth making, so I would say proceed.
. Also I just did a test, and it turns out they're applying http response caching, and returning 304's when our cached copy is still usable. Based on this I think we should follow that protocol. The fact they apply response caching means we can hit them as often as we want, and they will tell us when our cached data is stale.

. We definitely should eliminate the extra requests. There's no reason not to.
When I brought up the response headers it was in an effort for us to potentially re-think the way we do some of these things. If i can extend our http client with a robust, long-lived cache, and if we get our movie requests down to one, it opens the door for us to refresh in a much more powerful way. 
Right now the providers are unintuitive. Abo is under the impression that the refresh button in the library explorer doesn't do anything. The needs refresh algorithms, in my opinion, are a little too smart because the decision making is trapped in code and not in a place where the user can see it and control it. 
Contrast this with Metabrowser which has a "dumb" fetcher where if you tell it to process something, it completely refreshes everything. It's true that in order to get automatic refresh you do have to go and setup jobs, but at least the control is right at the user's fingertips.
I don't see this as a high priority but I'm just saying I think we can do better than what we have. What I'm proposing is not a paradigm shift, it is just a matter of shifting responsibility of where the cache lives, and using standard protocols to determine staleness, rather than internal algorithms.
. Michael - yes it does, but it uses the .net framework's built-in caching, which in turn uses temporary internet files. So while it does honor the headers, the cache isn't very large and data gets recycled quickly. So one idea is to disable it and use our own which would work off of etag, just like you mentioned and then all the different providers can benefit from it.
This is somewhat related:
https://trello.com/card/make-internet-providers-more-responsive-to-configuration-changes/50c03d2ab582e7483d002f1d/133
RIght now the user can change provider configurations, but having the refresh interval setting means they won't take affect until that expires, giving the impression to the user that the settings have no impact.
. Anyhow Michael, this is getting off topic, and what I've presented are just ideas for improvement. They may or may not see the light of day. I would still love to see you pursue the request reduction though. You'll have to make sure to test it with boxsets and make sure the saved json works.

. When we put together our list of assemblies to find types within, plugin assemblies come first. That's why it's currently working even though both your resolver and the core resolver have priorities of First.
But the core resolvers should be changed anyway so that they're not relying on this. The assembly order is completely independent and can be changed at anytime.
. This is very easy. Go to the MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations project -> Library -> Resolvers.
Find every resolver that overrides the Priority property, and bump each one down a level, e.g., First to Second, Second to Third, etc.
. It checks it within the actual Fetch method, so no, we're not running ffmpeg against all your files. There's a base class where NeedsRefresh is driven off of the item's last date modified as well as the last refresh result. It's done that way to avoid having the provider try again and again on failed extractions.

On Thu, Apr 11, 2013 at 10:20 AM, Eric Reed notifications@github.comwrote:

Even if we don't change this I want to store this information out here
somewhere so that maybe we'll stumble on it if someone else has this issue.
For quite a while now I have not been able to access the server that is on
my dev box from remote clients. The client could see the server via UDP but
not actually communicate with it after that.
I finally figured out what was going on here. Our UDP server returns the
address of the last network interface on the machine. My dev box had a
VM installe on it (it wasn't running but just installed - I had forgotten
about it) which had installed it's own virtual network interface. So, while
the UDP request worked fine, the address for the server that was returned
was for this virtual interface, not the actual one in the machine.
Should we not be returning the first IP address in the list?

Luke Pulverenti
. Folder-based browsing isn't going anywhere, but the ui developers have expressed a preference to tags because of the additional capabilities they provider. So I think that's where you're going to see the client-side efforts focused.
. This will be fixed in the next build but it is going to impact library scanning performance. Albums on musicbrainz have two id's - release entry id and release group id. Last fm gives us the former, while fanart uses the latter. We have to make a call to musicbrainz to translate the id's, and their api docs are very adamant about limiting to one request per second. Sure enough in my testing, anything more frequent than that and they start rejecting requests.
. Read what I wrote again. It gives us an id, just not the one we need for
fanart.

prompts you get during the setup process.

. we have some known issues with the log window. please disable it, then delete your library db and try again. 
. - Ensure episode and season resolver regex's function and return correct values.
- Update remote season and episode providers to support them
. We're not going to change the IndexNumber property, but what we can do is add an additional IndexNumberEnd property. This will allow clients to display the two numbers as desired.
. If you want to do that then you'll have to go into RemoteEpisodeProvider and have it perform an additional http request to get the info for the second episode. Then you can just concatenate them. If the user already has local xml nothing needs to be done because mcm already concats them.
. No, I wouldn't add a new field, I would just concatenate it into the existing overview. If we extend it to split them it will not be supported for mcm or metabrowser users.
. You know what. I would say let's do this in two phases. For now, let's just satisfy this issue by recognizing multi-episode file names. we can think about how to handle metadata later.
. The first phase is just to get the system to recognize the fact that it is a double episode file. That happens within the episode resolver. There's a very complex regex that gets run against the file name. This will have to be updated so that we can extract the range. Then an additional property will have to be added to the Episode entity. Perhaps EpisodeCount indicating the number of episodes in the file, or perhaps a nullable IndexNumberEnd. (IndexNumber is our generic property for episode number).
Step two is then updating the remote episode provider to get metadata. But hold off on that because I am refactoring the way we get metadata for tv series, seasons and episodes. We're going to be downloading metadata for the entire series all at once so that we don't have to perform individual http requests for each episode. That will be checked in later tonight, hopefully.

. I think this is a bad idea. The reason why we're seeing people trying to force types is due to the presence of the Type tag in xml. It's name implies some kind of function to it.
The collection types are actually helping solve this, and there's several improvements that will be in the next beta that I think will address many of the type resolution issues. I don't think it will be as much of a problem when tomorrow's beta goes out. So please re-evaluate after that.
But the main reason it's a bad idea is that it's not solving the problem at it's root. The reason why something gets misidentified is because the library structure guidelines aren't being followed, or a bug. If we give people a way to force a type, then they won't bother to fix the folder.  As a result, other parts of our system aren't going to work, and the true problem will be very difficult to hunt down. Users will show us the symptoms they are seeing and it will take a long time to trace it back to the fact that they forced a non-standard folder structure.
This could lead to the worst of all possible scenarios - where we have to start loosening up the server in order to accommodate these forced items that don't follow the library guidelines.
Example - a movie folder containing a video file that is not a supported extension. User forces it to a movie. It winds up with no media info, all ffmpeg and ffprobe operations will fail and it will not be playable. When the user complains about this, it will be difficult to trace it down to the fact that they forced it to a movie, but when all is said and down, it will just lead back to the original problem that we don't support the extension they want.
We've gotten this far without putting lipstick on errors and I don't think this is a good time to start. A better solution is just to trace each issue to it's root. The answer is always invalid structure, which leads to three possible outcomes - user error, bug, or something that just isn't supported (yet?). The more we hunt them down, the more the problems will go away on their own (collection types are going to help).
. Sorry, I see what you mean. The presence of the video file in the folder should result in a whole new item, with a new Id based on the way GetMbId works. On the scan that should cause a new child to be discovered and the old one dropped.
So we probably want to figure out why that's not happening. 
It's probably because the when the movie folder gets added, the containing folder gets marked for refresh by directory watchers. When the video file gets added inside, only the new folder gets refreshed. We would have to go up two levels, which the directory watchers don't do. So that's something to think about and experiment with. In any case, the next complete scan should correct it, although we obviously don't want to wait that long.

. This will be in the next dev build. The param is Indicator=Watched. Omit this param otherwise.
I did this with a webdings check mark because text is much faster than using an image, and webdings should be available on other platforms.  It basically looks like the MBT indicator.
In normal scenarios there's no real impact to cache size. It is how Grant first suggested. It just replaces the image that would have been there. The only way this can impact the cache is if the user browses their library with Roku, then goes on a rampage marking things watched/unwatched, then goes back to Roku. Even then it's not likely to have a big impact because the indicator is drawn on the final output, after re-size, where the image will already have been shrunk.
In other news, I also added a Format param, which accepts bmp, gif, jpg, png. If omitted the behavior is identical to as it is now. You might be able to re-enable cover art and use format=jpg. There is some transparency in the indicator and it looks fine with jpg, although cover art is obviously considerably more complex so I'm not sure how that will pan out.

. can you rework this to use the resolution normalizer? because clients specify their max values and the server determines the output based on that. for example, client might say max resolution of 1080p with a max bitrate of 2mbps. The bitrate would normally be higher but the user lowered it for network reasons. At 2mbps h264, 1080p is too high so the resolution needs to be lowered. The client still indicates 1080p because that's what it supports, but the server adjusts based on the other params.

. Yes you are correct. We have adopted kodi naming standards and after going over the supported formats and the unit tests, I believe this is by design. Without a separator between the episode number and episode title, it is difficult to handle the situation where the episode title is a numeric value or starts with a numeric value. That's why all of the supported conventions either use a separator, or use a prefix on the numbers, for example, S01E01.

. the ItemsService change should have no effect because apps have been instructed to pass all dates as utc. Can you confirm?
. Yea i understand but that's a breaking api change that effects every app, and also, for other types besides episodes, UTC is preferable. In fact, UTC would be preferable for episodes as well if that's what the provider data gave us. Unfortunately what we need is different behavior strictly for episodes and that's just going to create too many trickle down changes of other places that will need adjustment as a result of this change. Alternatively, this can also be fixed in a more surgical manner at the time the by date episodes are imported into the library.
. This is going to require changes everywhere. Apps are instructed that all dates passing in and out of the api are utc. when we save to the database, we convert to utc. This would be perfectly fine if all the provider data was utc, which it actually is for live tv but not all others. Sorry, but right now i would rather just handle the specific issue surgically.
. Because even though we are converting to UTC for storage and transfer, we are making sure to convert back when needed for use with the providers, effectively undoing the conversion. It is only the by date episodes that have a breakdown somewhere that needs to be remedied, and I think it is at the point in which they're imported into the library, but I'll know for sure when I actually dig into it.
It is the best of a difficult choice, either a fundamental api change or a quick fix that tackles only the specific issue. The api change would be really difficult due to the generic api that we have. It would force us to tell the app developers, if you're dealing with type X assume UTC, but type Y assume local. that would be really messy. In a perfect world the provider data would be UTC, but it is not so we have to make the best of it.
. No they are not because you haven't thought about the effect on the other media types where we do have appropriate utc data. In any application with an api it is always preferable to pass all dates across service boundaries as utc, and that is the way we designed the server api. Unfortunately we learned a little bit after the fact about the way the providers handle the dates, but it can still be handled by ensuring that any manipulation on the date objects is undone at the appropriate stages.
Your comment about just plain wrong is not really looking at the whole picture, because there are other areas where that operation is reversed when the original value needs to be manipulated.
. We could have that property on the server if we really wanted, but we need another way of expressing it through the api, either just documentation or something else, just to avoid fattening up the output of every single item. But that really should be treated separately from this, because this is something we can fix on it's own without having to do all of that.

This feature could be added to the htmlvideoplayer component.. We probably have some things to talk about. For starters, in the Emby web app, the video OSD UI is owned by the app, but in Emby Theater, it's owned by the user selected skin. In other words, the OSD is not attached to the video player, they are completely separate.  (And I see you've noticed that). This approach not only allows for skinning but it also allows for the same OSD to be re-used with alternative video players (windows, samsung, linux, raspberry pi, etc).
So if you pop the video player out and navigate back, you are no longer on the OSD screen anymore. So there are a few possible approaches here:


Just have the video player own it's own mini OSD for docked mode. This would require some duplication of effort for whatever features end up going into the mini OSD.


Do a minor rework to the OSD to separate it out from the page and into a component that can be embedded into any element. 


In the latter approach I would imagine something like,

navigate to videoosd.html, this creates an instance of the OSD and attaches it to the OSD page. When the user navigates out of that page, you could then destroy the OSD instance attached to the page, and the docked container could create a new one. Or you can look for an approach to retain the same OSD instance.. Nick, can you please send me a PM in the emby community, thanks.. Where is http coming from though? I'd rather keep that knowledge as opposed to just having a catch all.

If you're free to help continue with this, we also need to find a tree that doesn't depend on jquery (or just roll our own):

. We have been backtracking out of Polymer due to two specific reasons - first, there are too many quirks with their elements when running in browsers that are not based on Chromium. If you look at the web client source history you'll see I was maintaining several of my own fixes within the elements before dropping them.
The second reason is performance. The elements look great but don't perform well in browsers not based on Chromium, and even then, you can feel the overhead of pulling in and processing all of the html imports. It's just a little too heavy for me right now.
I am in favor of pure web components though and you can see some examples here: https://github.com/MediaBrowser/emby-webcomponents/blob/master/emby-input/emby-input.js 
These are much lighter, more minimalistic and more stable. They do require some compromise, for example, you might have to render out
<label><input /></label>
instead of just
<input />
But to be honest, I am OK with making that kind of trade-off. It is similar to the trade-offs you'd experience if you tried to move from Polymer to material-design-lite.
Additionally keep in mind, Emby Theater is targeting smart tv deployements, and the browsers on these tv's are often very primitive. We've been OK with polyfilling registerElement but back when we were trying to pull in all of Polymer it was just a no-go.
. So in terms of where we are with moving away from Polymer, it is completely gone from Theater and the shared components. It is also completely gone from the browsing side of the built-in web app. It is only when you move to the dashboard side that you feel the pain of both Polymer and jQuery getting pulled in. But we have replacements ready for everything that's being used, I've just been doing the actual replacement little by little as it's obviously very tedious.

. This is currently working as expected.  The caching headers being applied are conditional (weak), due to the fact that the url has nothing but library Id's. Therefore if we switch to strong caching, there is currently nothing in place to bust the cache if the source file changes. If you look at the images api, we put a caching value in the url, basically the equivalent of an Etag. This allows clients to cache forever based on that url because if the image changes, so too will the url. In order to switch to strong caching, we would need some kind of an api change such as that.
. https://github.com/MediaBrowser/Emby/commit/dcf3509ea28e1bb0cdc3ada16432cfb50b08aac4
. See: "there is currently nothing in place to bust the cache if the source file changes". That's what I added in my commit which then allows the normal caching mechanisms to be used. What you did in range request writer was just repeating the same response headers that HttpResultFactory already writes.
. Yes, some of them were, with conditional (weak) caching. If you look at the control flow of the caching headers you see the difference between conditional and unconditional is the presence of a cache duration. The consumer up in the api layer was not supplying a cache duration (and rightfully so), therefore it was only getting conditional caching based on last modified and etag. I updated the api layer to pass in a long cache duration which now steps it up to unconditional and allows the client to cache forever. But before this could be done, we first had to devise a way to change the url if the file changes because that would be the only way to force the client to download it again.
. Ok, then yea for transcoded output that would be expected because we don't know what the final content length is going to be. The range request writer doesn't even get used for that. That's the progressive stream writer up in the api layer.
. Yes that is conditional caching which was already there. That requires the client to come back and check if it has changed via conditional requests. Unconditional says you can keep your copy until X expiration date without ever having to come back to see if it has changed. The only way to bust that is with a new url altogether. Granted with a large video file this is unlikely to ever be a problem, but it is possible for music.
. ok, what is the exact difference?

Ultimately, what you want to do is just follow these instructions:


Is the path you want to edit a top level folder that was added in Emby library setup? If yes, then use the web interface to edit library setup as desired. That's all you need to do, and after you make changes it will kick off a library scan.


OR, is the path a sub-folder or media file? If yes, then do whatever you need to do directly in the file system. Then once you're done, run a library scan and Emby will pick up the changes.

. If you read the referenced discussion you'll see the issue :).  It depends on what you are ripping and how you are doing it.  The issue is that it is sometimes recognized too quickly - before whatever is needed to identify that it is a movie.  In that case, you end up with it resolving as a folder and nothing that happens after that short of re-scanning or restarting picks it back up as an actual movie instead of a plain folder with sub folders.
Right now, this can be avoided by lengthening the amount of time we wait between changes to the file system but, as Luke points out in the other discussion, this is just a hit or miss/get lucky way of solving the issue.  It would be nice if we could be a little better about properly identifying things during the rip process.
This isn't a huge issue as it mainly only affects folder rips which, I don't think a lot of people other than me do.  Also, it can be addressed by the individual by fine tuning the file system watch delay to their liking.  I just want to keep this open to see if we can do anything else about it.
. For now, we can just plan to educate people on the adjustment of the delay if it becomes a problem.  We have bigger fish to fry...

. To clarify again the install process.  When you click on the link to "setup.exe" you need to "RUN" that program, not download and save it somewhere to run over and over again.  The next time you want to install, you need to go to the web link and run setup.exe again (let the browser re-download and re-run it from the temporary location).
Basically, you need to be sure you are always re-downloading the "setup.exe" program.
. When you click on a link in a browser that is an executable file, you get the option of either saving it or running it.  I'm saying to run it.  This is in IE.  In chrome, it downloads it automatically and then shows it on the bottom bar where, if you then click on it, it will run.
This is what needs to be done each time if you are installing outside of the dashboard because yes the setup.exe does change.  That file is not even our setup program.  It is the ClickOnce pre-requisite installer.
So, you need to treat our installation just like you do Chrome (they use the same technology).  You always click on the link in the browser, let it download and run that exact copy of the setup program.  Do NOT save that setup program somewhere for future use as it is transient.
Sorry if all this is confusing.  I'm probably making it sound harder than it really is.  Basically always click the link and re-download/run the setup.exe every time you install.  That's all.

. Did tmdb change their API again?  It was necessary to make the separate calls in order to get all of the info we needed.  They re-worked this in v3 of the API.  It creates multiple requests but individual payloads are lighter which is what they were going for.
As for the box sets, they have changed the way that works a couple of times.  We used to be able to get full movie data back for a box set but they changed it so that it only returns a sub-set of it.  It is (or was anyway) a subset, though so the same result object should still work.
. According to the current documentation, it doesn't look like this has changed.  With your changes, we will no longer get country-based release and rating information, images or any cast info.  Is all this somehow working for you?
. > Also, the value is a class level value in highly concurrent system - it's my understanding there's only one instance of the class. I'm making that variable a local variable once I get the chance.
To what variable are you referring here?  Results are deserialized into instances of the class in question that are local to the executing method.  There should be no concurrency issue here.
. > The only thing in common between movie and collection right now, is "id", "backdrop_path" and "poster_path". 
And, unfortunately, that is about the only data that is returned for collections right now...
. The release info result is searched for the specified country.  This is how we get proper ratings and release dates for the user's country.
You are getting full image and cast info from the single call?  This is not how it is documented to work in v3.  It is how it used to work in v2.
. I see now you are talking about the ItemType variable.  Yes, this is a problem.  That is a vestage from MB2 where each item had its own instance of the provider.
. For boxsets, we could do them separately now.  They were combined because, when they first implemented the collection data, it returned the exact same information as a movie.  This was nice because we got genres etc.  Then they "fixed" a bug and we now have a separate call and very limited data for boxsets (what they call collections).  I put in a request almost a year ago to have that data expanded but it hasn't happened.
. > The feature I'm using in TMDb is the "append_to_response" which allows you to take any of the other sub-requests (releases, casts ..) and add them to the current request. I just add all the pieces we need :)
Ah, I see.  That was the bit that I missed.  Very cool.  Just be sure the object we save is identical to how it was before because the json provider needs to come back and read that.

Appearantly I suck at high-traffic git projects. So I might have done something wrong while getting the upstream changes. I might discard my fork and re-do my changes in a seperate branch.

The only thing I've found that works reliably right now is Tortoise Git.  Sucky interface but seems to not stuff up the repo like Git for Windows does sometimes.  You might also look at SourceTree.
. One other thing you could look at here would be splitting the images out into a separate provider.  This would allow independent control of the metadata and the images.  For instance, you could retrieve just the meta or just the images if you had the other one locally already.
. No, I think his changes are okay.  The part I missed was the append_to because github cuts off the source lines with no way to scroll right - so I never even saw that on the request url.  I think that must have been an addition to the API since I re-wrote that provider for MB2 - or, I just missed it back then.
Anyway, that call reduction should be fine as long as we preserve the saved json format.
. There is no reason to re-fetch from the net 95% of the time.  The saved json relieves the load on tmdb and makes our re-scan process much faster.  It is integral to the design of the providers.
We either need to preserve it in its current format (preferred since we already have a bunch of it out there) or re-write the json provider to properly read whatever the new format is.
. I really don't think that's a good idea.  It will still slow down our re scans - especially if there is no net connection at the time.  Plus, they limit our hits and concurrent hits.
There is no good reason to hit them again when we already have the data locally.  The savings we are getting with the multiple request reduction is only a 1-5% case.  Eliminating our local copy of the data is a 95% case.
. Just to further explain - Right now, the only time we even touch tmdb is the very first time a movie is added to the file system (assuming save locally is on which it is by default).  This carries forward even to the situation of a clean install on a new machine - as long as the media folders are still there.  Even if the user deletes their cache and library db, we still won't hit tmdb for these items again. So, cutting this request down from four to one is a good thing but only helps us in this one instance of the very first time a movie is discovered. And, the payloads are identical.  The only thing being saved here is the overhead of the multiple requests.
If we eliminate our local json and it's provider we are now hitting tmdb on every library scan.  That just doesn't make any sense to me.
This data is relatively static.  Once it is there, it is there and doesn't change much.  Our current system is very efficient with this type of data.  I'm for the new request type but we have to make our save locally functionality work too.
. I'd also love to see you look into pulling the images out into their own provider if you're up for it...
. If I get time and he doesn't get to it first, I'll see if there is a way to implement his consolidation of calls and still keep our compatibility with the existing saved MBMovie.json.

. This isn't to eliminate mapped drives. It is to eliminate the situation where the user sets up his directories as local drive references because he has MB3 server on the actual media server machine.  If they do this everything will appear to work until they try to actually play something from MBT or MBC.  Then it will fail because the Path reference is unreachable from that machine.
This situation is not intuitively obvious to the normal user so I think it would be good for us to remove it from the equation.
. I don't understand.  There is no choice in this instance.  It simply won't work if they use a local drive reference...
. And, mapped drives, actually will be an even bigger problem for us than it is for MB2.  In MB2 it is a problem because Windows likes to disconnect mapped drives after periods of inactivity and they aren't always re-connected at startup which causes all kinds of pain for us.
In MB3 we could have the same issue with mapped drives that we do with local ones.  If all the locations aren't mapped to exactly the same drive letters on all machines it won't work and it won't be obvious why.
Translating everything to UNC will solve all these issues and not remove any power from the user.
. > That depends on what client they use. I plan to have mbt stream when the file is not available. (It'll have to stream anyway in order to handle the youtube plugin).
So, what will happen is some user will ask why the quality sucks on his videos and he can't get any 5.1 audio or they'll just give up because it sucks and it will be because they set it up with local drives.  But there won't really be any way for them to know this.
. What, exactly, is the harm?  I've laid out several benefits to doing this.
Basically, I'm saying let the user pick his directories how ever he wants to.  If they want to point to them with the local drive (because that's what they'll do because, if they're on the same machine that's what it will look like they should do) then fine.  We just translate that directory they chose to a universally acceptable reference.
We haven't removed any control or options from them at all.  We've taken their choice and stored it internally in a way we are sure will work in all instances.
Where is the harm in that?
. So display a message telling them we translated it.  And, if it can't be translated, tell them that too.
What I'm suggesting makes the process much easier for the normal user.
. What if instead of translating them behind the scenes, we simply eliminated the option of using the local drive letters and always force them to go through the network paths?  
Using the network paths is what we will want them to do anyway, it shouldn't make any difference even if the content is local to the machine and it will eliminate all confusion...
. conversion would be for the people who don't even know what a UNC path is - they would select the drive but we would change it to UNC.
However, I'm sure this won't be as easy as it sounds so anything we can do to educate and have the users make the proper choice up front would be good.
I also will be looking at static streaming in MBC soon but that will still not be the optimal solution.

. Interesting side-effect of our new userdata identification technique.  Actually, I think it is accurate and not sure it should change...
For the purposes of user-specific data like resume point and favorite, etc., we identify the items by their IMDb id instead of our arbitrary file system Id.  This way the information lives with the item even if you move its physical location.
The side effect being what you are seeing there - all copies of the same movie get the same data.  Since they are, in fact, copies of the same movie, I think this is correct.

. A couple questions:
1) Did you happen to have an explorer window up where that episode lives or any other files in that area open in some other program?  Like editing something with notepad or downloading an image or using metabrowser/MCM?
The watcher saw the change but there is logic in there to not kick of a scan until whatever you are doing is actually finished.  This way we don't constantly scan the library over and over when you are in the middle of a 45 minute rip process.  So, the watcher saw some file in that same area as being open and was waiting for it to be freed.
Once that happened, it would have cancelled the current scan and kicked off a new one.

All of the information you provided above is technically correct, but it must be balanced with the actual vulnerability and need.  We are securing access to media content that is stored already within a (most likely) insecure file system.  If one were to gain access to the physical Emby database, they have gained access to that file system and, therefore, any passwords for our system are irrelevant at that point.
Also, most of the clients do not store any form of a password on their end (hashed or otherwise).  Instead they store an access token that can be readily revoked at the server end requiring the client to re-authenticate.
Security is important to us and we have made improvements in this area and will continue to do so.  However, there are many practical factors to take into account when doing so.
. Since we are open-source, any hard-coded key or certificate in that source is readily obtainable.
. Check out the Swagger docs available from the tray menu of the server.  Particularly the "Users" end point.
. The server doesn't necessarily run under the local system account because it may need access to network resources - in which case it needs to run under specific credentials to do so.

. This is by design at this point in time.
We install to the user-specific area instead of a common location because this is the only way we can ensure our automatic update routines will work completely unattended.
Given that, we install to the first admin account to minimize the situation where someone installs the server multiple times on the same machine into multiple different user accounts.
. I'm pretty sure the only reason we elevate right now is to cause the server to be installed into a single, repeatable user account even if the user installs it from multiple users.
This elevation can probably be removed with the only repercussion being that the server will get installed into whatever user account is running the installer.  We cannot go into a common area (other than the admin user area).  We have been down this road and it simply isn't reliable.
If someone wants to make the change to the installer such that it doesn't request elevation and thoroughly test it with both existing and new installs, then I'm game for that.

Thanks..

tikuf:
Aart and Boris here are some parameters for you for hls. I'm not sure that there is currently provision in the api for a stream of 64kb (no video)  (I suspect Luke will correct me if there is) but apple have this as a requirement to get the app in the store.
Hls Settings
Bitrate Pairs & Resolutions 
A 64000,V (nil), (no video param This is not in the server yet I don't think)
A 64000, V 150000,MaxWidth=640,MaxHeight=360
A 96000, V 300000, MaxWidth=640,MaxHeight=360
A 128000, V 1000000, MaxWidth=1280,MaxHeight=720
A 128000, V 1500000, MaxWidth=1920,MaxHeight=1080
A 192000, V 2000000, MaxWidth=1920,MaxHeight=1080
A 192000, V 2500000 , MaxWidth=1920,MaxHeight=1080
The max widths and heights are only a guide and can be altered at your discretion (they are currently imho resolutions at which the videos are view-able) Obviously a 1080p stream will not be able to have a bitrate of 100kb p/s.
Video codec will always be h264 for hls.
Audio codec can be either mp3 or aac {AC}.
Recommend 2 Chanel (if you are coding for a device that has surround capabilities then 6 chan can be used but only with aac) {CH}.
Audio sample 44100 {ASR}.
So your basic url will be something like>
http://{server}:8096/mediabrowser/Videos/{id}/stream.m3u8?VideoCodec=h264&VideoBitRate={V}&MaxWidth={W}&MaxHeight={H}&AudioCodec={AC}&AudioBitRate={A}&AudioChannels={CH}&AudioSampleRate={ASR}
The top video setting should be considered as a max value due to apple requirements that segments be under 5meg this will probably not be much of an issue since the top 3 settings should only be for a home network but I think we should stay within their spec.
Users will have to be mindful that their upload on the network the server is on will have to be able to sustain the upload rate with this in mind the middle setting may also be unsustainable unless they have a very fast net connection.
Any questions don't hesitate to drop me a line here or on the board (or by messenger).

. To get the interlace/progressive flags ffprobe has to decode the video using the  -show_frames param it does this for each and every stream in the file unless you actually specify to run it for video only with the -select_streams v param.
There are problems with this because.
1. The show frames is executed before any other options in ffprobe.
2. There is no way to limit the output (ie the number of frames) that ffprobe returns info for it does the whole film not matter what (loads of requests to change behavior but no movement from ffmpeg devs).
3. The returned info is not always correct although it is for the most part).
4. Using the -select_streams v will return no info for audio or subtitle streams.
here is a sample of what ffprobe puts out for every video frame in the video (below is progressive)
        {
            "media_type": "video",
            "key_frame": 1,
            "pkt_pts": 1048559,
            "pkt_pts_time": "11.650656",
            "pkt_dts": 1048560,
            "pkt_dts_time": "11.650667",
            "pkt_duration": 3753,
            "pkt_duration_time": "0.041700",
            "pkt_pos": "964",
            "pkt_size": "573445",
            "width": 1920,
            "height": 1080,
            "pix_fmt": "yuv420p",
            "sample_aspect_ratio": "1:1",
            "pict_type": "I",
            "coded_picture_number": 0,
            "display_picture_number": 0,
            "interlaced_frame": 0,
            "top_field_first": 0,
            "repeat_pict": 0,
            "reference": 3
        },
As far as I can see the only way to get the interlaced/progressive status of the file would be to run ffprobe and return the usual MI the run it again with the -select_streams v -show_frames params (only) read the "interlaced_frame": X, output then kill off ffprobe once we have that value. I'm not sure we want to do all this for the interlaced/progressive MI but atm as far as I know its the only option.

. ffprobe will report channels as 6 on 6 channel source
. If we want to get the right number of channels from bdinfo we will have to take the .1 (or .2) and just add it to the previous number or just define 5.1=6 7.1= 8 etc
. This is by design (ish) if the device consumes no media for a time ffmpeg quits so we don't have multiple instances transcoding different files (if you change your mind and start watching something else). We may need to alter the api so there is a distinct difference between pause and stop.
. No it's not making them up. I would suggest its just reading a different version of id3 tags than the one you are seeing.
Of course I may be wrong. Check all versions of the tag in an external program make sure that genre doesn't appear in a another tag.

. This is bizarre but yes apparently there is a numbering scheme for id3 tags (I believe it is universal) but 50=Darkwave as you have discovered, 10=New Age, 19= Industrial etc etc. The name to number was invented I suspect to save space in the file. As i said I don't think it is just ffprobe/ffmpeg thing, it may be but I don't know.  
Anyhow it can be solved by simply adding a  "The"  in front of your 50s,60s,70s,80s tag.
As this is something out of our control I think this can be closed.

high cpu  - (as is now i think we could cut wait for segments to 1 or 2 here as well) would produce close to 100% cpu but allow seek faster in devices that support it
medium cpu - (threads 2) we would have to change the wait for segments likely to 1 would likely cut the cpu to about 20-50% depending on cpu (a bit less than webm uses now)
low cpu (use -re param segment length of 5 seconds wait for segments 1) cpu on most modern cpus would be between 5 and 20%. The -re is an input option so it would be ffmpeg -re -i blah
further to that
http://mediabrowser3.com/community/index.php?/topic/2280-transcoding-in-mb/?findpost=49992 (more up todate)

OSJF:
If I recall, Windows Media Player saves one or even two different images of an entire album and saves it hidden as something like "album_x.jpg".
I'm wondering if extraction currently takes place every time your run the plugin? Or image data gets stored into some cache for long time usage?
Also - I'm only familiar with album image extraction technic's from the user view, they tend to save a single image per album. I don't know how players behave with more or even thousands of songs inside a single folder.
I always felt Media Players generally tend to become unresponsive sometimes when it comes to handling album views, more or less. Imho, recent Windows Media Player versions do handle album views pretty good, iTunes does to I think. Maybe it's worth a look how they do it and implement something similar or even better? :)

LordMike:
@ebr11 
The only thing in common between movie and collection right now, is "id", "backdrop_path" and "poster_path". :P
. > With your changes, we will no longer get country-based release and rating information, images or any cast info. Is all this somehow working for you?
I just made a quick test with my API. Calling the main /movies API with a language set, will also affect the outcome of the images and votes fields. As for country release info, this seems to be a list of dates for all countries, no matter which language we're requesting with - which makes sense since we never specified the country.
Btw. do you know a movie with different casts for different languages?
The API doesn't allow languages to be set when fetching casts, so I don't see how it's possible for it to return different data based on any language/country property we set.

And, unfortunately, that is about the only data that is returned for collections right now...

Wouldn't it make sense to handle collections and movies differently? Or maybe media browser doesn't store info on boxsets (like all movies in a set, in order to find missing movies).. (I really don't know, haven't looked into it) ?
. > They were combined because, when they first implemented the collection data, it returned the exact same information as a movie.
Aww .. That sucks :|
I agree, the previous form would have been better, but sadly the gods have decided otherwise. :/

You are getting full image and cast info from the single call? This is not how it is documented to work in v3. It is how it used to work in v2.

It seems that way. I have yet to find a movie with so many images that I can't get all. The feature I'm using in TMDb is the "append_to_response" which allows you to take any of the other sub-requests (releases, casts ..) and add them to the current request. I just add all the pieces we need :)

I see now you are talking about the ItemType variable. Yes, this is a problem.

Appearantly I suck at high-traffic git projects. So I might have done something wrong while getting the upstream changes. I might discard my fork and re-do my changes in a seperate branch.
. The saved json will not be preserved.. :/
Unless we do some hack where we promote the f.ex. the cast and crew lists to the parent container, without disrupting the JsonDeserializer.
Isn't there some way to make MB re-fetch everything if it detects an update has happened?
. @LukePulverenti 
Your client already respects 304's and sends e-tags (I think it was that). The only thing now would be to extend the lifetime of a cached request. As you already have a central HttpClient implementation, I think we can do this.
Without any research, I would say a simple approach is to store each page we'd like to cache (perhaps under a certain size, certain mimetypes etc) in a directory with a form of {url-hash}-{etag}.cache. This way we can find them again. But this should be in another issue :P
EDIT: I looked into your client, and it seems you're already using the built in caching. Adding a long-lived cache would probably require some manual work, as I can't seem to find a built in mechanism for this.

. Yea, I was worried about the performance. On desktop you don't even notice it but the number of new DIVs was a concern. I think it's the rendering that's causing the lag and not the actual looping. I didn't rewrite the entire guide, I just "fixed" it so that shows actually reflected when they started/ended and some shows that were hidden would be displayed.
I wasn't as concerned about the shows being hard to read right at their end because you can always hover over them and see the titles. Showing the current half hour may work but it would still potentially display shows that have ended (if it was only 15 minutes long). I think the better solution may be to display it sort of how I did but stretch the width of the current partial 30 min block to be the same width as 30 minutes. There would be a bunch of things to consider with how it will work however.
But, someone else can do all that. Since there was absolutely zero feedback from the people who could merge this either approving it or asking for specific changes or fixes I'm not going to bother spending time to rewrite the entire guide code to support a more robust solution.
. Ok, well if it's actually going to be reviewed and (ultimately approved) then I can spend the time rewriting the entire thing to be more efficient.
. I did some thinking and testing and I don't think that doing exactly what tadams88 is suggesting will work. There is a chance that no show is scheduled in a particular timeslot. Not entirely sure if I should even worry about that but if we looped thru the programs and there was a gap between two there would be a problem.
I rethought the old method that was used and I think I have come up with some good changes. First I removed all the individual DIVs used for "time slots" and am using the programs to fill those spaces themselves and then creating a filler DIVs if there isn't a program scheduled (if it ever happens). This reduces a single channel's DIV count from 1440 to the number of programs (~40-50). I also realized that I was being stupid checking every minute. If a program is running nothing else can be on at the same time so it now won't check until the time the current program actually ends. This change reduced the number of times I looped thru the programs from 6160 to 152 (on my 7 channel system).
I'll try get some more people to test and confirm that everything behaves as expected and then update the pull request.
. My gut feeling is that having everything absolutely positioned would create additional overhead in browser rendering.
I could do what you suggest with removing each program but not sure it is going to make a big difference. It's looping thru only the programs for the specific channel at a time so the array is only going to be 50-60 items at max. More likely it will be a lot less. On top of the splice I'd have to create a new global variable (which shouldn't effect too much).
Let me know what sort of performance you get with the new update compared to the last test you did and we can take it from there (updated files are on the forum. I didn't want to keep making pull requests here to test. Or PM me if there is a better way to work/test this)
. Good news, testing looks good with partially populated channels or channels with no data. I also stretched the first partial time block the same as WMC does it.
(I'm sorry about all the lines where just the spacing changed but I couldn't fix it to match no matter what I did)
. I've removed the last functionality that would cause 1000s of DIVs to be created. Now if there is no program at a specific time, or no guide data, I am finding the next program on that channel and making the spacer DIV large enough to fill all the space. Worst case scenario this replaces 1440 DIVs with 1 DIV at the expense of having to loop thru the list of programs for a given channel one time each time there is no guide data.
. The CSS had to be fixed because the way it was setup before was that every 30 minutes was a block in the guide, that DIV had a border on it regardless of whether the program actually ended there. Then the program DIV was on top of that and hid the borders in the intermediary DIVs. This makes no sense so I changed it to have the border on the actual program DIV. The display is the same but it's more efficient.
I also changed the width of 30 minutes to be evenly divisible by 30 so I could have a fixed width for "1 minute".
. All the spacing has been fixed. It should be much easier to read the diff now.
. Changing it down to 10 minutes will make it happen less but still won't fix the problem. Shows end at odd times not just on evenly divisible by 5/10 times. From looking at the TV guides of people in Europe it seemed even more common for shows to NOT end on a 5/0 then to end on one.

. have the people who are experiencing long startups, run sysinternal process monitor. For me 99% of the startup time is as mediabrowser enumerates its cache and ibn prior to getting to the system tray.
FWIW i think theres not a 100% 1-1 to relationship between cache/ibn size and startup time. Startup time seems affected by how the cache/ibn was built re: metadata fetch and store configuration. . I store all my tv as seriesname (release year)....seriesname (YYYY). This use to help MCM with disambiguation
. Just been testing moving over to full MB fetching (by removing all my local metadata).

So perhaps the  tvdb fetcher just needs the 'pidgeon logic' of if series have (YYYY) and IF 'Seriesname (YYYY)' doesnt exist  then try 'Seriesname'.
This would allow all shows with multiple instances in different years to be 'disambiguated' and all folders on filesystem to be consistent (with their year of release).

Tharnax:
Not sure if Beta tester input is appropriate here but given myself and another beta tester (Jacklynee) both ran into this issue, I feel this issue t is going to come up often.  Personally, I didn't even notice the Network option when I first setup the server, I know the drive and folders my media is on so I went directly to the local folder structure.  Obviously, from both of our posts in the Community forums even with the UNC path warning, we didn't realize that had to do with how we setup our media libraries. Given the way MB Server and MB Classic is shaping up with MBT ont he way there appears to be the need for a more appropriate mechanism in place to direct individuals to setup UNC paths and not local folders if in majority of instances the ultimate player is going to be looking for the media on a networked device.  My $.02 for whatever it's worth.
.
DGMayor:
I did mine as UNC be default only because I had the knowledge to do so from prior experience.  The idea behind MB3 was to make is so easy, you don't need documentation.   If you're not knowledgeable  about the way network shares, permissions, UNC paths etc work, you could run into issues by not doing this from the start.  
I definitely think there should be text reminding the user to make sure their media drives are shared properly, but I do like the idea of translating them to UNC automatically and invisibly.
. Would it be possible to test for shared access and give a message regarding that as well?  UNC paths are kind of useless when they don't have the sharing and user rights configured properly.
. Don't you need your library set up with UNC paths for MBC to work on any other machine other than the one hosting the files?

This one just got me when trying to test MBC. Thank god Redshirt keeps up with all the bugs here. I was about to go crazy. I run a vmware instance on the same server I run MB3 on. This may actually be why I have always had trouble with the functionality the UDP server provides. Should this be configurable by the user...even if only manually for those that run in to this rare case?
. Luke, don't you know what IP the server app is bound to? Can't you safely just assume that the UDP server should broadcast that address?
. Hmm, then if the UDP app is going to guess, why not use the IP of the server host name? At runtime you can retrieve the hostname of the machine you're running on, resolve the IP, then broadcast that? IMHO, something needs to be done with this before we have a bunch of new testers come on board. Right now, I have no way to configure Eric's MBC app.
. I must not be thinking clearly and I certainly know very little C#, but are you saying that you are currently taking the host name and resolving its IP and using that for the UDP server for broadcasts? If that's true, I don't see how the wrong IP was broadcast. If that is not what you were saying, then can't you do something like this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1345676/how-to-get-the-server-ip-address to use for the UDP broadcast? Again, I may not be understanding something, but this seems like the way to go and appears to be trivial to do.
Btw, I also agree that each client should be able to configure manually since firewalls play a part in this as well.
. I admit complete ignorance when it comes to .NET so forgive me if this suggestion makes me look silly, but wouldn't one of these methods work in this case? - http://www.geekpedia.com/tutorial149_Get-the-IP-address-in-a-Windows-application.html  If nothing else, you could build a list of available IPs. Then present them to the user if more than one are found for them to pick from during setup? Or make it an advanced option.

Or have a config setting that allows that behaviour. i.e. for remote linux boxes - a watcher just detects a change of some sort, and it schedules a scan for a short while later, then rely on the scan to find the new content.
. Luke - what about deletions? e.g. Just deleting an Actor from the series metadata - will that cause the actor to be removed from the series in MB3 as well?
. This looks to be working fine to me. I've added actors, deleted actors, split double names, and everything worked properly.
. Luke - this is a related issue: when an episode has guest stars, their name(s) can exist as a pipe delimited list within the  <GuestStars> element, but they can also exist as Person elements (with roles) within the <Persons> element.
The current version of metabrowser takes the GuestStars field from TVDb and parses it into the more complete  <Persons> node.
It looks like MB3 is preferring GuestStars as whenever the same person exists in both lists, the one without a role takes precedence.
I think you should use Persons in preference top GuestStars (with an episode xml file).
. OK, I'll check it out when the next release is available.
(I just noticed that my comment lost some of the text as I'd used less than and greater than characters around some element names in some places (GuestStars and Persons) - I''ve just edited it to make the < & > visible.)
. @ebr11 this is working now, with the Persons list taking precedence over the GuestStars list. 
It wopuld be good if there was a standard way that roles could be assigned on TVDb - I have noticed that occasionally roles in parentheses are appended to names, and that MetaBrowser parses these and splits them out properly into the Persons list. But according to this post the TVDb admins don't seem to approve: http://forums.thetvdb.com/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=9123
. Here's a few other possibilities:
I'm sure most users would have their local trailers and music videos in separate folders away from their TV and movies - perhaps another, easier, solution would be to put some sort of tag at the end of the containing folder name - eg. [music videos] or [trailers] - that way anything found under that folder could be included in a different view.
Or, have reserved folder names (like"Music Videos" and "Trailers") where all their contents would be included in a different view.
Perhaps this would be the easiest - against each collection have a checkbox that determines whether that collection should be included in any of the views or not. 
. So, how about the checkbox idea (last paragraph above)?

dot-i:
As requested I will reply here to the questions you sent me via PM on AVS:
-- start reply --
There will be no issue supporting Mono at all since you won't need the actual SDK you ran your tests on ;)  Simply use any REST-client library you like and talk directly to the http end-point on port 49943. For example: https://github.com/restsharp/RestSharp which runs just fine on Mono.  REST is the way forward and the SDK you looked at is the "old" SDK still using WCF.  I plan to move ARGUS TV to a full REST api in the future, phasing out the WCF endpoint and SDK.
The documentation is spread over the C# SDK you looked at (it has a .chm help file) but the REST api itself is also self-documented up to a reasonable point if you browse to its help pages. Some more details here: http://www.argus-tv.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=73&t=3946
Cheers,
Nico

. Can we have GM both on the server and on MBT so we can do client side image processing ?
. Well, if you are dealing with photos you want to access the EXIF data so you can rotate the orientation as required to match the camera. The GraphicsMagick convert tool supports the -auto-orient flag to do this.

A nice way to do this is to have the baseItem have a auto-orient flag and so the server will take care or the rotation (if required) before presenting to the Client.
Also, when we move to imagemagick or sooner can we also add a bunch of image data to BaseItem - i.e. actualWidth, actualHeight etc that will make photo display much cleaner and easier
. :+1:

. The only program that doesn't work with LF is notepad. Projects using LF instead of CR+LF is normal, don't assume everyone works on Windows.
That absolute path in MediaBrowser.ServerApplication.csproj is a bad idea. What if a developer is using a 32bit windows? There is no "Program Files (x86)" on his system. Or if his primary drive is not "C"?
Since you just wanted to change your last commit you should have used amend instead of revert. To get rid of all those commits, and end up with only one you should squash your commits. If you are using git from a shell use:
git reset --soft HEAD~7
git commit
If you are using TortoiseGit go to the log (right click --> TortoiseGit --> Show log)  --> select the commits --> right click and choose "Combine to one commit".
After that you will have to push using force (-f).
Also you should probably have used the dev branch instead of the master.

What you need to do is rebase your branch on the remote dev branch. . Any changes you make in a branch (including rebasing) wont affect any other branch so it's safe to rebase. If you are afraid you might break something, create a new branch from your master and rebase that.
Note that your "origin" probably refers to your fork, and not to this repo. You'll have to add a new remote pointing to MediaBrowser/Emby instead of softworkz/Emby, and rebase on that remote's dev branch.
In git even if you do break a branch (for example if you delete a branch, or you do a hard reset) the old commits are still there for some time (I think the garbage collector will delete them only after a couple of months has past) even if you don't see them anywhere. As long as you know the old commit hash you can create a branch using that hash and the log will be exactly as it where. You can find md5 hashes of "deleted" commits using the reflog.

. Can we get some feedback on this?
. I only added the identities to baseitem so that image providers could access them during the refresh without having to make very extensive breaking changes. Ideally, it wouldn't be there. If a single item were refreshed, the identities would be recalculated and populated at the beginning of the refresh, wouldn't they?
This is work that is currently done at the beginning of each metadata provider, and is then immediately used inside that provider, and never made available to others. The item identities allow the identification  portion of each provider to be run for all metadata providers as a separate phase, which means that all identities are available to all providers when they start trying to fetch the item data. It also allows the identity converters to run in between these two phases, and fill in missing identity information.
The new interfaces are entirely optional. I have only implemented them on the TV items, partly as an example, but mainly because those are the ones I need for the anime plugin. Any of the other item types could implement it if someone found they needed it.
. Well, the image providers still have access to the information that they had before, so they could fall back onto the previous logic if there are no identities (I just checked, and I did not implement this). However, if the previous run was actually using the identity information, then the refresh might pull down the wrong images.
I guess we can either persist the identities, or always run the identification pass when refreshing anything on an item.
. @ebr11 
Well the first thing to mention is that it is optional. Unmodified providers continue to work just as they are.
This change introduces the concept of an item identity. These are a little like the provider IDs that we are currently using, but they store more information specific to each type of item.
For example, this is the item identifier for a TV episode:
``` c#
public class EpisodeIdentity : IItemIdentity
{
    public string Type { get; set; }
public string SeriesId { get; set; }
public int? SeasonIndex { get; set; }
public int IndexNumber { get; set; }
public int? IndexNumberEnd { get; set; }

}
```
The Type on the identifier functions similar to the key in the provider IDs dictionary. The identity is supposed to provide all of the information needed to fully identify the item.
If an item type has an item identity implemented, then you can define IItemIdentityProvider<TLookupInfo, TIdentity> implementations, which are responsible for identifying an item.
During an item refresh, all of the relevant identity providers are run before the metadata providers are run. The metadata providers can then retrieve these identities while they are fetching their metadata.
The main purpose of this, is that in between the identity providers and the metadata providers, the identities can be used to create new identities. This will allow the anime plugin (or any similar plugin in the future) to insert conversion between thetvdb IDs and AniDB/Hummingbird/AniList IDs before the metadata providers run.
@LukePulverenti I would also rather the property were not there. Passing it along to the image providers during the refresh will require some breaking changes to the image provider interfaces, and we will likely have to always run the identifiers even when only refreshing images.

. Just to help explain a bit why the css is using positioning: to allow for easier grouping of video controls, and to allow for left/right alignment I opted for positioning the containers. Here are some examples to better illustrate:

 Attempting to use relative positioning would result in the need for negative top margins, which I thought would be even more confusing.

The absolute positioning allows left and right alignment easily without bothering with floats and widths.

Even if the widths are set wider than they probably should be we don't have layout problems - it is just a little more forgiving.

This is a good example of how the grouping/alignment is working.
Of course all this can be achieved with a more simple layout, but I thought the control grouping worked well and overall I found it to look nicer and more aligned to what I would expect from other video players. We don't need to keep this css layout if you don't like it.

. Boy, learned alot about the channels and twitch tonight - good stuff.




Twitch is an odd one - it only lets you take 100, and you get them in the
order they want to provide them in, which is based on viewers. Overall the
api is a little clunky, so it makes things a bit hard too. Basically
though, we get back the top 100, and then somehow those are being alpha
sorted - but it is a false alpha sort since the order is really "arbitrary"
(based on viewers). You could easily have games with names from A-Z in the
first 100 and 101-200, so alpha is misleading. However, alpha makes it
easier to find unless we implement search. ideally, I think we'd be able to
override the channel item sorting and just "take what we get" so to speak.
I'll chat with you more about this tomorrow.

Two. imagemagick across all the distributions are all compiled differently. Debian and Ubuntu do not seem to include webp which is the default compression we use. Additionally, imagemagick in the distros is compiled to do threading on each image, which is good when processing large image files. But in our case we are trying to process reasonably sized files but lots of them so its better if we thread the process ourselves. Also, we use a better compression algorithm q8 rather than q16  for better performance.

. I was checking out your changes and it looks like the nvec one includes a bunch of merges from dev. I'm guessing you were trying to update your branch to the current dev version? What git commands did you use?
. I don't know about fixing your branch. It's pretty mangled. What I can do is tell you the proper way to rebase your changes onto a branch.
First you should ALWAYS work off a new branch. In this case you should be working off of the dev branch but with a new branch name. After your initial fetch open up a git shell and run the following (omit everything after \ it's meant to be commentary:
git co dev \change to the dev brach
git branch YourNewBranchNameHere \ create a new branch
git co  YourNewBranchNameHere \ change to the new branch
git push --set-upstream origin YourNewBranchNameHere \ push the branch to your remote repo
At this point you have a new branch called: YourNewBranchNameHere that is based on current dev. Do all of your work in this branch then submit a pull request. If it's accepted there is nothing else to do. 
However, dev continues to change while your pull request sits there. At some point you need to integrate the dev changes into your branch so your pull request can be merged. The first thing you need to do is get the dev changes into your local repo.
git fetch upstream \ bring in changes from the official media browser repo
git co dev \ change to your dev branch
git merge upstream/dev \ merge the changes from the official repo into your local dev repo
                                       \ since no changes were made to the dev branch because all work
                                       \ was done in YourNewBranchNameHere this will merge conflict free
git push \ sync to your remote repo
At this point you have a local dev branch that mirrors the official media browser branch. You now want to bring those changes into YourNewBranchNameHere. But the result you want is your new changes replayed ontop of the dev changes so they can be easily merged.
git co YourNewBranchNameHere  \ change to your new branch name
git rebase dev \ This is what does the magic. 
The command git rebase dev will unwind any of your changes merge in the changes from dev into YourNewBranchNameHere then attempt to replay your changes on top. If there are no contlicts you can just do a git push and you are done.
If there are merge conflict you will need to fix them. They are marked with the standard git conflict resolution markers. Then run:
git add [Conflict files] \ Each file with a conflict needs to be re-added individually after resolution.
git rebase --continue \ signal all conflicts are dealt with.
git push -f \ you need to force since this is a non continuous change.
If you have any questions feel free to ask, but I recommend creating a new branch and just re-doing your work there.

. The public and private key are a pair. How would you suggest we keep the private key a secret since we are open source and don't host the server software? If it's not secret we might as well use http as anyone can decrypt the traffic. 
Also, we cant override certificate validation errors on roku or windows 8.1 store apps. (There may be other platforms that don't let you do this as well) 
Pinning only prevent MITM attacks by spoofed certs from bad cert authorities.
. Hosting a CA as you are suggesting has nothing to do with certificate pinning. Certificate pinning is just telling your browser (or application) what the public key\certificate for your well known website is. This way, if a bad CA which was in your trust chain did issue a cert for a pinned website, the browser or application could tell you. (See the following: https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Pinning_Cheat_Sheet) In other words, pinning basically prevents a MITM attack even if someone has obtained a cert for a website illicitly that would otherwise be valid in your trust chain.
All of that said issuing an emby CA root cert with the private key well known to all and allowing users to generate ssl certs from it isn't a bad idea if we were able to override the certificate validation process on all platforms as we would NEVER want the cert in the OS or browser trust chain. I'm not sure if this is possible but will do some digging on it.

. Hi Luke
Can you take a look at these changes, they are working nicely for  me.
I was not able to make suitable tweaks within FFMPEG (in particular trying to override the frame size within the QSV encoder caused a lot of strange results - I think because the rest of FFMPEG expected the original values to be used and not my overridden values).
Questions
I've made a couple of other tweaks too and have a couple of questions...
CRF
I'm not using CRF based encoding - In most documents I've read, since we are streaming at a particular bit-rate the most important thing is the bit-rate. Therefore the setting that should be changed to affect quality should be the -preset. The slower the preset the better the quality will be at the specific bit-rate. 
This could mean low end CPUs may not be able to keep up, but this is why I would have thought it would make sense to use ultrafast | fast | slower as the options that change when the user selects a quality.
Rounding factor
I have added some logic to use a different rounding factor if using QSV. Based on the code I've added, the values for any other codec should remain unchanged.
Maxrate confusion
I noticed here:
// H264
                if (hasFixedResolution)
                {
                    if (isHls)
                    {
                        return string.Format(" -b:v {0} -maxrate ({0}*.80) -bufsize {0}", bitrate.Value.ToString(UsCulture));
                    }
That the -maxrate would be less than the bitrate when we have an HLS stream, in my edit I have set the h264_qsv -maxrate to be 20% higher than the bitrate because - but have I overlooked something here?
Scaling method
Finally, you'll notice I have added a scaling method which will be appended to the existing scaling options - :flags=fast_bilinear - This is because I found that with the default method I was getting about 25fps with low CPU and GPU utilization (something was clearly not working correctly).
After switching to this different scaling method, I was getting about 55fps with 75% GPU and 85% CPU utilization

On 18 January 2015 at 19:19, Mike notifications@github.com wrote:

I don't know about fixing your branch. It's pretty mangled. What I can do
is tell you the proper way to rebase your changes onto a branch.
First you should ALWAYS work off a new branch. In this case you should be
working off of the dev branch but with a new branch name. After your
initial fetch open up a git shell and run the following (omit everything
after \ it's meant to be commentary:
git co dev \change to the dev brach
git branch YourNewBranchNameHere \ create a new branch
git co YourNewBranchNameHere \ change to the new branch
git push --set-upstream origin YourNewBranchNameHere \ push the branch to
your remote repo
At this point you have a new branch called: YourNewBranchNameHere that is
based on current dev. Do all of your work in this branch then submit a pull
request. If it's accepted there is nothing else to do.
However, dev continues to change while your pull request sits there. At
some point you need to integrate the dev changes into your branch so your
pull request can be merged. The first thing you need to do is get the dev
changes into your local repo.
git fetch upstream \ bring in changes from the official media browser repo
git co dev \ change to your dev branch
git merge upstream/dev \ merge the changes from the official repo into
your local dev repo
\ since no changes were made to the dev branch because all work
\ was done in YourNewBranchNameHere this will merge conflict free
git push \ sync to your remote repo
At this point you have a local dev branch that mirrors the official media
browser branch. You now want to bring those changes into
YourNewBranchNameHere. But the result you want is your new changes replayed
ontop of the dev changes so they can be easily merged.
git co YourNewBranchNameHere \ change to your new branch name
git rebase dev \ This is what does the magic.
The command git rebase dev will unwind any of your changes merge in the
changes from dev into YourNewBranchNameHere then attempt to replay your
changes on top. If there are no contlicts you can just do a git push and
you are done.
If there are merge conflict you will need to fix them. They are marked
with the standard git conflict resolution markers. Then run:
git add [Conflict files] \ Each file with a conflict needs to be re-added
individually after resolution.
git rebase --continue \ signal all conflicts are dealt with.
git push -f \ you need to force since this is a non continuous change.
If you have any questions feel free to ask, but I recommend creating a new
branch and just re-doing your work there.

neagix:
This type of implicit behavior feature should have been at least disabled by default, as of now it is impossible to start Emby without SSL, because the check in ApplicationHost.cs about CertificatePath being empty always returns false (albeit it is truly empty in configuration).
To make things worse, EnableHttps seems to be checked only by UI and not by the actual code that starts the HTTP server.
Edit: I am not sure how CertificatePath gets set to non-empty string along the way (although I assume it's due to this feature), but at this point I think we could do two things:
1. use EnableHttps as a server-side option too instead of just client-side OR
2. add another option for the auto-generation of certificates (filling in the hardcoded true in the call to GetCertificatePath()
By the way, generally speaking a method named GetCertificatePath should read something and return it back; a more correct name would be now GetCertificatePathAndGenerateItAsNeeded
Edit 2: nevermind, as I read more I understand it's working as it's supposed to be working, I was just looking for a way to not enable SSL at all
