TheTedAdams:
Just tested this pr on my Nexus 4. I timed how long it took to render the guide after the page loaded (starting when the popup appears, and ending when the popup disappears).
dev: 1s, 1s, 1s
pull-request: 21s, 21s, 20s
Decreasing the cell size from 30m to 1m seems to have a very negative impact on mobile performance. This might need some performance tuning.
I do think it is a good idea to allow programs to be displayed accurately to-the-minute. I think we would get better performance from re-working the code to iterate through the programs once, and place each program in its appropriate spot, rather than iterating through the cells and then iterating through the programs once for each cell to find the correct program to put in that cell.
I do agree that the starting time should not be the beginning of the hour, but using current time means that the currently playing program is completely illegible for the last 15 minutes of the show. Personally I would rather see the most recent half-hour, instead (e.g. 1:00, 1:30, 2:00, etc.). I think this is how the guide works for Comcast at least.
. What I was suggesting would be a major overhaul of how the guide is rendered. The only reason is because that's how I tackled it when building a proof-of-concept guide overlay for the video screen. It involves calculating and setting the size of the program container, and then positioning each program absolutely based on calculations of where it should go. It seemed to be a pretty performant approach, but I agree that if we can get the functionality improvements we are gunning for without such a major overhaul, that would be the better option at this point.
I didn't realize that we still had a div for every minute, sitting underneath each show. That should be a very helpful fix for div count. And good move on skipping slots that are already filled. That will cut WAY down on iterations through the programs array. Love it.
I wonder if the program iterations would be even more efficient if after we found the program (around line 175) we added programs.splice(i, 1); That would mean each iteration gets shorter, and saves us from iterating through programs that have already been placed. The only question there is whether the cost of calling programs.splice() once per program found would be more or less than the cost of iterating through already found programs. My gut says the .splice() would add efficiency but might be worth a perf test.
Or, if we are sticking with 1 minute increments, I wonder if there would be a performance gain from turning the array in to an object with date.setSeconds(0) as the key.
``` javascript
var programDict = {};
programs.filter(function (curr) {
        return curr.ChannelId == channel.Id;
    }).forEach(function(curr) {
        try {
            var time = parseISO8601Date(program.StartDate, { toLocal: true })
                                .setSeconds(0).getTime().toString();
            programDict[time] = curr;
        }
        catch (err) {
    }
});

```
Then the programs could be retrieved by calling programDict[date.getTime().toString()] instead of iterating through an array?
Dunno, just bouncing ideas around.
. What you just sent me in PM is a massive performance improvement. Great work. Back down to ~1s to render the guide on my Nexus 4. (A lot better than 20s!)
If we are at 1sec render time we probably don't need to worry overmuch about tweaking out every last bit of performance. So just ignore my rambling musings :)
One last thing would be what you mentioned with stretching the first cell out to 30min width, regardless of how long it is.
This is how WMC shows the guide at 4:59, for instance

Having a 1min sliver makes it look at-a-glance like the guide didn't render correctly, just in my personal opinion

If you can figure that one out, I think this would be an awesome improvement to the guide!

paul-777:
I have reworked it - turns out the issue was that we weren't detecting anamorphic removal as upscaling so we were passing in the current video bitrate as the limit and many of my 720 res anamorphic 21:9 videos have bitrates less than 800Kbps so were then being scaled down to 640 rather than upscaled properly. For example a 720x432 anamorphic video which should be upscaled to 1032x432 was being down sized to 640x268.
. Unfortunately I don't have that capability to be able to test it.
. Channels? All I have is the media on my own storage. I can't see why the changes would affect media where we can't obtain mediainfo though - if the IsAnamorphic flag isn't set it the metadata then it will have no effect. Which in itself will mean that those anamorphic streams (many live TV broadcast are) still won't be upscaled properly, but won't be any worse than the current situation.

. Hi Luke, 
Upscaling of anamorphic content is the correct thing to do though - down scaling them results in half the pixels and a very poor quality image compared to the intended resolution, and in fact results in 20% less pixels than the anamorphic source which clearly isn't great (based on normal DVD formats). Just because we allow the bitrate to go higher to achieve this doesn't mean it will actually go to the maximum rate given, so even if a client did pass a max of 100Mbps it is very unlikely that any content would upscale to that - you would likely need to find a 70Mbps anamorphic source to cause that to happen. Also anamorphic content is typically restricted to DVDs so even the upscaled version will still have a lower bitrate that an HD stream - which means that if clients are specifying a max bitrate that allows them to work with HD stream then upscaling of anamorphic should be no issue at all.
Actually in my own build I don't limit the output bitrate based on the source bitrate, only by the max specified. (remember this is a max not a target) The reason for this is that when transcoding I am often reading a highly compressed stream and encoding quickly with a lower compression ratio so in order to maintain output quality the bitrate has to rise. With the default restriction in place transcoded bluray rips looked terrible on a big screen. This is was most noticeable when we were triggering level41 -> level40 transcoding of a 1920x1080 stream, the quality drop was huge. The only reason I can see for limiting the bitrate based on the source is if we feel that the max bitrates, resolution etc. requested by clients are not accurate and we need to "help" them with that decision. 
The anamorphic detection now allows for a small amount of distortion without flagging it as anamorphic which should prevent issues with badly encoded streams. If it does get flagged then the distortion would likely be noticeable visually.

altf4:

. Good comments! For sure, the only way to ensure confidentiality when submitting user credentials is an end-to-end encrypted channel. No amount of client side hashing can solve that problem. HTTPS being mandatory would be a great step forward for security. Though that can be considered separately from the question of how to store credentials in the backend.
@jabbera One option to consider for for certificate validation on thick clients is certificate pinning. The idea is that rather than using the Certificate Authorities built into the platform, you create an Emby CA, hardcode its public key into the thick clients (Android app, Roku app, etc...), then have the client validate against that CA. It effectively bypasses the main weakness in HTTPS: The certificate authorities. It's more secure (because you're only trusting one CA and not the whole list of foreign governments in the default CA list) and more convenient.
What this would let you do is provide (perhaps just to paid subscriber people. Monetization opportunity!) an Emby supplied HTTPS certificate that their thick client apps will just recognize and be cool with. No need to (perhaps unsafely) ignore SSL errors. The only area where this doesn't work is in the browser. There is no thick app to hardcode a cert into. But perhaps manually accepting a funny SSL cert one time in the browser is worth it "just working" on all the other platforms.
Certificate Pinning
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Certificate_and_Public_Key_Pinning
Thanks!
. @ebr11 You are correct that HTTPS is really necessary for a secure transport of credentials to the server. But supposing that this is impossible for some reason, it is still a security vulnerability to send client-hashed passwords as Emby currently does. 
It feels strange, I know. But consider every major website on the Internet. Until relatively recently, sites like Google, Facebook, and Twitter had HTTP as the default, and an optional HTTPS site. (Similar to Emby's current configuration) And what they did was send plaintext passwords via HTTP, and hash them on the backend. That is the most secure option.
. Not true. The EFF's HTTPS-Everywhere project was created specifically because of the problem of major websites having HTTP as default. In each of these cases, user credentials were being sent in plaintext over HTTP, before the switch.
HTTPS-Everywhere
https://www.eff.org/HTTPS-EVERYWHERE
2011: Twitter announces option to use HTTPS by default
https://blog.twitter.com/2011/making-twitter-more-secure-https
2013: Facebook switches to HTTPS default
https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook-engineering/secure-browsing-by-default/10151590414803920
2010: Gmail switches to HTTPS default
http://gmailblog.blogspot.com/2010/01/default-https-access-for-gmail.html
(They had a user option for it, previously)
. Good question. It is a hardcoded public key, as in asymmetric cryptography. So it is not a secret. The reason you hardcode it in the app is to have a secure way of distributing it, in the same way that every other CA certificate is distributed in the browser. 
Public Key Cryptography
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public-key_cryptography
. Just to recap: The certificate pinning thing is just a suggestion for a possible way to handle HTTPS for thick client apps. It's really separate from the question of how to store credentials once the server has received them. If you would like, I could make a separate github issue to implement (and discuss) certificate pinning. 
To answer your questions, I am not familiar with the Emby backend infrastructure so it's hard for me to say definitively what's possible, but it does not require anything major. Pinning is something that is really common for app developers, and a good security measure. But it can definitely be described as a "nice-to-have".
TLS certificates come in two halves: private and public. The public certificate is the thing that the server sends out to clients in order to prove who it is. This certificate is not a secret and is the thing that you look at when you view the certificate for the current website you're at. For example, here is Github's public TLS cert:

The web browser knows to trust this certificate because it has been issued by DigiCert, which is a certificate authority built into the browser. The certificate authority system is the main weakness in HTTPS, since any certificate authority is capable of creating a valid certificate for any website, thus being able to spy on it. There has been lots of precedent for CAs being compromised by hackers or otherwise coerced by local governments, so this is a real issue.
Certificate pinning solves this problem by creating your own certificate authority, and telling your app "Trust only this CA, and no others". This drastically reduces your surface area for risk in HTTPS. There are no TLS error to ignore, since clients will be given a valid certificate signed by an authority they trust.
So you would in fact need to keep the Emby CA private key a secret, but only in the same way that any other site (including every other open source project) keeps their TLS keys secret. I noticed there is an HTTPS site: https://connect.mediabrowser.tv/ It would be no different than that.
I hope that helps. 
.
xmob:
But by sending a password hash and comparing it to the hash in the database, you are sending passwords in plain text.
How things are at the moment is the same as sending the password in plaintext and storing the passwords in the database as plaintext.
.
telyn:
You could automatically generate the private key on startup. However I personally feel like this is over-engineering it. I agree with @altf4's original post and @xmob - the current setup is equivalent to storing passwords in plaintext on the database. Storing passwords salted and hashed, and have the client send the password in plaintext (over an encrypted transport) is all Emby really needs to do in my opinion.
For over-the-internet situations, let it be up to the person installing Emby to provide the SSL certificate and keys for their hostname. What I myself do is place Emby behind nginx and use nginx for SSL termination, but I admit that I haven't investigated how my Chromecast connects to it in that case.

XmlTV. What we did there was create a standalone class library and I think

make sure it has unit tests along with some sample files.

targeting Win 8.1/.NET 4.5. That is really the best approach right now for
dual compatibility with .NET and .NET Core.

the library just work with a Stream. The unit test project can then use the
full .net 4.5 framework and can pass in a FileStream. Let me know if this

. Well, if the UI is of no interest, then there is no point in looking at metabrowser.
The workflow you described, is exactly what I had implemented anyway.
Now I have changed my implementation as you requested: The matching strings are now stored in the AutoOrganize config and the UI for deleting those strings is within the dashboard's auto-organize section.
The workflow is as follows:
1. A file fails Auto-Organization because the Item-(Series-)Name cannnot be resolved
2. The user can now organize the file manually from the Auto-Organize Log
3. I have added an option to this dialog to save the match string:

1. If the option is checked, the match string is saved to the autoorganize.xml file and in the future, all files with this string are automatically matched to the library item
2. I have called this feature "Smart Match" and added a UI directly in the dashboard:

Currently match strings can be deleted only. Probably a method for adding custom strings, will not be required anyway. It is just important to be able to review the smart match configuration and to correct undesired settings.
What to you think?
. Regarding translations: Can you suggest a tool to edit all string files in a synchronous way?
Regarding style: I am already using the existing styles  - actually I copied a few bits from the scheduled tasks page. What's do you think is wrong? 
PS: I just tweaked this a bit to get series names bigger and match strings smaller. But I will gladly leave the visual tweaking up to someone else..
. OK, good to know that. I tried some localization tool and it screwed up all files..
. @psxlover: The important thing here is, that we are NOT matching against the filename. We are matching against the series name that emby has extracted through its regex patterns and cleanup methods.
For this reason it is very unlikely that euhd is the series name and elefantastisch an episode name, because this is already the parsed result.
As to the second case: Yes, currently you have to repeat the procedure for a title with a different release group. But cases with more than two or three different release groups are probably rare.
But I understand your idea and I had thought about that, too. The thing is: Before this change, emby was matching the regex-extracted series name by exact comparison: exractedName == seriesName.
My change keeps that method, it just adds alternate recognition strings.
What you are proposing would be a substring match. E.g.: the extracted name is "zzgtv-anger" and you would like the user to be able to change this through a textbox to "anger". In order to make this work, the matching would need to be changed from exact matching to substring matching. This is a bit dangerous, because when there is another series containing 'anger' in the title, it would be incorrectly organized. You may say, that this is a rare case, but there are even more implications with substring matching: The watch folders may not just receive tv series episodes but also movies or songs or some other stuff. This makes it very likely that - at some point in time - you may receive a file where the regex-extracted name contains the word "anger" and this file would be organized incorrectly. Due to the automatic handling with file-move, folder deletion and renaming, you may not even notice what has gone wrong.
=> This is why substring matching is a very bad thing in that case.
I thought about that for quite a while, but in the end I always came to the conclusion that substring matching would cause many more problems than it would solve. 
Of course, you will have to go through the organize correction dialog two times, if the files are from two release groups, but that is at least much better than doing it 24 times for a single season...
. A future improvement I have in mind would be this: Once you have completed the correction dialog and checked the "Smart Match" option, the server could go through the failed log entries and retry organization. This would help in cases where you already have an amount of failed files in the log (e.g. all containing 'zzgtv-anger'). 
Edit: This is unnecessary, because the other files will be picked up during the next organize run anyway!
. This feature is now also included in #1202

Here are some examples where the X-Application-Error-Code header is needed to indicate the actual error to the user:
- User opens and completes the correction dialog for a file that does not exist anymore
- User opens and completes the correction dialog for an existing file but the file cannot be copied to the target location (drive or path not accessible, file in use, no access permissions, volume full, etc.)
In the current public release, the correction dialog just remains visible forever in all of these cases. This behaviour is even more irritating when you consider the fact that in case of a successful completion, you will experience a similar result: The correction dialog remains visible until the file move operation is completed. As a consequence, the user keeps waiting and waiting assuming that he's waiting for the file move operation to complete while in reality the operation has failed long ago.
I think it is important in these cases to indicate such failures to the user not only as a generic message (like "An error has occured") but also provide some useful information about this error. The X-Application-Error-Code provides exactly this, so I did not look any further.

Click on "Movie"

- Select an item from the result view or click Cancel and you will be returned to the previous dialog
- There you can also select a base target folder from a list containing all of your library folders for movies
- Click OK and the movie will automatically be organized according to the choices you made

- Click "Identify"
- Choose series from search results or click "Cancel"

. ...rebased to current dev branch.
. Added server side locking to prevent duplicate item processing and changed the autoorganize list to display a processing indicator.
Please see the following video: https://youtu.be/Lq4RGXVh_os
. AutoOrganize: Instant completion of correction dialog 
When the autoorganize correction dialog is submitted, the server service waits just 2s to complete the request.
These 2s are to wait for an exception that might occur. In this case the exception is forwarded to the client and the web UI will immediately display a message overlay with the error message.
Otherwise the ajax call is returned after 2s and the dialog gets closed in the client UI. The organization progress is then displayed in the autoorganize list (orange text color and spinner animation).

. AutoOrganize: Make LeftoverDeletion and EmptyFolderDeletion also work with manual organization:
Previously the auto-organize features LeftoverDeletion and EmptyFolderDeletion only worked when organization was performed through the internal scheduled task.
This commit makes these features also work for all manual organize operations:
- Organize via correction dialog (series or movie)
- Retry organization when target is already set (series or movie)
- Delete file
To make this work in various situations, the code for these two features was refactored into FileOrganizerBase.cs without functional changes.
This commit also improves the automatic search term for movie organization.
. Over the time I always tried to extract certain changes to a separate branch.
Sometimes it works, but sometimes it doesn't. I always tried to isolate changes as good as I could, but in this branch there are too many changes where many of them are depending on others. 
I am testing my code every day on quite a few real world scenarios. I think I have achieved a state which is rather stable and really worth looking into it.
I know that this has grown quite a bit over the time, but looking at the details, it is not that much stuff that has changed.
To help you a bit looking through the changes, I have compiled a minimal list explaining all of my changes. It should be in the same order as it is presented here on github.
. -   MediaBrowser.Api/Library/FileOrganizationService.cs
  -   Added properties for new series organization
  -   Added method for movie organization
  -   Added methods for Smart Match entry management
-   MediaBrowser.Controller/FileOrganization/IFileOrganizationService.cs
  -   Added Dictionary for InProgressItems
  -   Added methods for movie organization and for Smart Match entry management
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/AutoOrganizeOptions.cs
  -   Added SmartMatch options via composition
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/BaseFileOrganizationRequest.cs
  -   Created as a base class for the existing EpisodeFileOrganizationRequest and the new MovieFileOrganizationRequest
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/EpisodeFileOrganizationRequest.cs
  -   Added properties for new series creation feature
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/FileOrganizationResult.cs
  -   Added some new properties: IsInProgress for dynamic progress display in the client and two others for movie organization
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/MovieFileOrganizationRequest.cs
  -   New class for movie organization
-   MediaBrowser.Model/FileOrganization/SmartMatchInfo.cs/ SmartMatchOptions.cs
  -   New configuration classes for the SmartMatch feature
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/EpisodeFileOrganizer.cs
  -   Made subclass of the new FileOrganizerBase
  -   Changed options usage up one level (AutoOrganizeOptions instead of TvFileOrganizationOptions) to enable access to SmartMatch options
  -   Parse and store movie naming to optionally allow treating a file as a movie
  -   Already save result at the beginning of the function to enable dynamic display of organization progress
  -   Also perform LeftOverDeletion and EmptyFolderDeletion on manual organization operations
  -   Implemented SmartMatch feature to remember certain strings as item identification
  -   Improved error handling and error display – generally and especially in PerformFileSorting()
  -   Implemented series matching via SmartMatch strings
  -   Fixed bug when providers don’t return episode titles
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/FileOrganizationService.cs
  -   Added ConcurrentDictionary for items that are currently being processed
  -   All returned FileOrganizationResult objects are updated with a valid IsInProgress property
  -   Can now handle episode as well as movie corrections (depending on result.Type)
  -   Implemented a new Websocket message "AutoOrganizeUpdate", to tell the client to update its organize list
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/FileOrganizerBase.cs
  -   Base class for the existing EpisodeFileOrganizer and the new MovieFileOrganizer
  -   All methods which are common to both variants were moved here
  -   Implemented cleanup of parsed movie names for movie organization
  -   Implementation of features “LeftOverDeletion” and “EmptyFolderDeletion” was moved here
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/ItemInProgressException.cs
  -   New custom exception which allows specific handling of this exception in certain situations (=> throw error on manual organization, ignore errors and continue during auto-organization as task)
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/ItemProgressLock.cs
  -   New class to implement locking and status of items currently being processed
  -   Implements IDisposable to enable usage with minimal code by employing the using-pattern
  -   Throws ItemInProgressException is item is locked already
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/MovieFileOrganizer.cs
  -   New class implementing (manual) movie organization
  -   Currently the primary file is copied/moved only. This should be improved a bit in the future
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/OrganizerScheduledTask.cs
  -   Just added some new dependency services
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/FileOrganization/TvFolderOrganizer.cs
  -   Added some new dependency services
  -   Removed “LeftOverDeletion” and “EmptyFolderDeletion” features which were moved to FileOrganizerBase
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/IO/FileRefreshItem.cs
  -   Item class for the new refresh queue
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/IO/FileRefreshQueue.cs
  -   Timed queue class refactored out from LibraryMonitor, now grouping all items by parent folder and independently processing these groups
  -   This approach is much more reliable/stable
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/IO/LibraryMonitor.cs
  -   Separated queue stuff into FileRefreshQueue
  -   Remaining code is very simple now
  -   FileRefreshQueue could be used for watching autoorganize folders (instead of polling)
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Implementations/Persistence/SqliteFileOrganizationRepository.cs
  -   I added two additional fields to the auto organize table to store the parsed movie name and year just in case that it is a movie that we are dealing with
  -   I did this for the following reasons:
    -   The SqLite variant provides a proven storage method from which I didn’t want to deviate, replace or amend
      I just didn’t want to come up with something where people could have thought that I wanted to outnumber anyone else or overtake the project lead
    -   Code changes were minimal for this, so it jumped right into my head
  -   Alternative: Generate these strings just on the fly and don’t store them in the db table
-   MediaBrowser.Server.Startup.Common/ApplicationHost.cs
-   Minimal changes

- GetDirectoryContentsOrFileSiblings

- IsFile

- GetFileDirectoryOrDirectoryPath

. No, this doesn't make any sense for a query either.
When a user enters a date range to limit search results, no adjustment should occur. 
The entered date should be matched/compared to the permiere/air date of the library item as it is officially recorded (and supplied by the providers).
. This is not limited to episodes, it is also applicable for movies and other items.
It's just a matter of logical consequence: 
- It is impossible to work with UTC dates. Not for series/episodes, not for movies, because we don't know the time zones for the provided dates
- Thus, we can't convert them to UTC
- The only option is to leave/treat air date and premiere dates as local (local to to the location of premiere)
- Finally, this would lead to the behaviour that the user is expecting anyway and nothing else.
Imagine a German user, searching for a certain US item by release date: He reads the release date on a US website and enters this date in the search (he would never convert that date to the European date and time before entering).
After all, I don't think that this change would break anything, it would just fix all issues.
Please note that the changes are limited to "PremiereDate" and "AirDate"! For other dates (e.g. like DateAdded) the timezone conversion is absolutely correct!

Please take some time to carefully think through what is happening here right now:
•Local Timezone is UTC+2
•Look at TvdbEpisodeProvider, Line 410
•DateTime.TryParse creates a date from the string in the xml, assuming this is a DateTime matching the local computers regional settings
•Thus, the next statement ".ToUniversalTime()" converts the datetime (assumed as local datetime) from the local datetime to a UTC datetime
•If the parsed date is "2016-03-30 00:00" the converted date would be "2016-03-29 22:00"
This is just plain wrong. It's not one out of two or more feasible alternatives to choose from (and to prefer due to compatiibility). The result is total nonsense and not even close to UTC.

. Today I re-assessed this issue, but I came to the same conclusion as previously:
- Assuming an externally provided DateTime as local and then converting it to UTC is always wrong (unless your local time zone matches the time zone of the external DateTime)
- I already gave an example to illustrate this
- You should also consider this: The premiere or air dates coming from the metadata providers usually don't have a time component anyway! 
- And these properties are displayed without time component in the UI!
- So the only actual effect of calling ".ToUniversalTime()" is that Emby will display incorrect dates (and incorrectly auto-organizes)

. This solution is not using an additional img tag. It is using an img tag instead of the div tag that was previously used. So, there is no extra element being used.
If we don't want to interfere with images that have transparency (eg a transparent border as those created by the cover art plugin), the placeholder background needs to be removed (or switched) just in the moment when the actual image is loaded and about to be displayed.
Since we agreed that we don't want an event based solution, there aren't much options left to perform that kind of image switching.
The key to the solution here is the img tag. The special behaviour of the img tag (and this behaviour is consistent across browsers on all platforms I tested) is this: If the img tag is displaying an image via its src property and the src property is changed from javascript, it keeps displaying the previous image until the new image is loaded and ready for display.
For css-backgrounds this does not work. When the css background is set to an image that is not yet loaded, the background is immediately cleared until the new image is loaded.
I also think that using img tags in an html view to display like 100 images is a more natural way than doing it with 100 div tags using css-baclgrounds. I don't have any evidence for this statement, but I would imagine that at least some browsers may handle 100 img tags with greater efficience than 100 css backgrounds.

. StringUsageReporter Class
This class contains tests for reporting the usage of localization string tokens in the dashboard-ui or similar.
Remarks
Run one of the two tests using Visual Studio's "Test Explorer":
-   ReportStringUsage()
-   ReportUnusedStrings()
On successful run, the bottom section of the test explorer will contain a link "Output". This link will open the test results, displaying the trace and two attachment links. One link will open the output folder, the other link will open the output xml file.
The output xml file contains a stylesheet link to render the results as html. How that works depends on the default application configured for XML files:
-   Visual Studio
  Will open in XML source view. To view the html result, click menu 'XML' => 'Start XSLT without debugging'
-   Internet Explorer
  XSL transform will be applied automatically.
-   Firefox
  XSL transform will be applied automatically.
-   Chrome
  Does not work. Chrome is unable/unwilling to apply xslt transforms from local files.

. Background:
- Enumerating files in a folder is a very expensive operation
- Opposed to this, accessing a specific file (or its properties) is an extremely cheap operation
- Purpose of the DirectoryService was obviously to avoid repeated file enumerations in a specific folder by caching the results
The implementation of the DirectoryService got one step too far, though:
To get information about a single file, it enumerated all content of the file's parent folder (which is expensive) instead of just returning the properties of that single file (which is cheap).
This fix changes the behaviour and will always directly determine the file information from the file system.

. This is the result of intense investigations about Chrome's behaviour regarding buffering of media content. Whatever scenario I tried, with different content files, different player frontends, different server behaviour (supporting range requests or not), or various HTTP response header combinations:
On any seek operation (no matter if large or minimal), Chrome always initiated a new http request and never used any local cached data.
Long story short: As opposed to most other browsers, chrome does not implement specific buffering for media content. Instead it just employs the default http caching mechanism. Thus, the solution was to add appropriate caching headers to the range responses.
Note: This commit only addresses serving of static files to the clients: Either files that match the client's device profile or pre-transcoded files (e.g. created from the FolderSync plugin).
. Finally, Chrome is using cached data on seeking when available:

. This solution used the cache key as ETag and the cache key is built from file path + last modified date, so it is a strong key!

. ## Testing the new feature
Here are some procedures for testing the new capabilities:
Hint: For more fun, open two or more browsers displaying the auto-organize log simultaneously
Test Realtime progress display

Put one or more files into the auto-organize folder (from which you know that they are identified correctly)
Start the Organize-Task
Watch how all new files are added to the top of the list in real-time, displayed as "In-Progress" while they are copied

Test instant dialog completion

Put one or more files into the auto-organize folder (from which you know that they are NOT identified automatically)
Run the Organize-Task and then open the Organize-Dialog for the file that couldn't be processed automatically
Adjust the settings and click OK
The dialog will close and you can see that the file is being processed
You don't need to wait for the copying to complete anymore. Instead you can immediately proceed with another file

Test dialog error handling

Put one or more files into the auto-organize folder (from which you know that they are NOT identified automatically)
Run the Organize-Task and then open the Organize-Dialog for the file that couldn't be processed automatically
Adjust the settings to a non-existing value (like season 123 and episode 987) and click OK
The dialog will not close but display an immediate error message instead
Thus, you can fix the problem and try to click OK again

Concurrency

Put one or more files into the auto-organize folder (from which you know that they are NOT identified automatically)
Run the Organize-Task and then open the Organize-Dialog for the file that couldn't be processed automatically
Adjust the settings and click OK
At the same time (while the first request is being processed), try process the same file from another browser instance (or the same).
The second operation will be blocked (also, manual and ScheduledTask processing can't simultaneously process the same file anymore)

. ## Benefits

The primary benefit is (nearly) instant seeking within a short range of the current playback position.
Primary use cases are things like skipping commercials or repeating scenes.
Depending on the client't browser cache settings, it's also possible to repeat a long sequence without additional network traffic.
Limitations
This feature doesn't help when skipping forward large timespans. In these cases it's difficult for html5 clients to determine the correct byte range to request on one side, and on the other side, the transcoding process might not yet have reached the skip destination.
In such cases, we are setting up a new transcoding session just like usual.
. PS: To demonstrate the actual benefit and effect of this feature, I added two new "Skip" buttons to the video player. The left button skips back 5s and the right button skips forward 20s.
. A few more remarks;
In order not to break any clients with this feature, the only viable solution seemed to me that a client must explicitly indicate that it can handle the feature. In our case that's these two aspects:
- The media file has a duration (although it's still being encoded/remuxed)
- The media is served via http range requests/responses
So I implemented the following procedure:
- When the client player calls "getPlaybackInfo" it can add a new parameter "CanQuickSeek"
- The server checks if all conditions for QuickSeek are met. If yes, it returns a streaming url containing the parameter "tryquickseek=true"
- When the client requests a stream and the stream url contains "tryquickseek=true", the server re-evaluates all conditions and will then finally set "StreamState.UsingQuickSeek"
- If the latter is true, the file will be served with a preliminary duration in the header and with support for range requests

But we need to think a bit further and from larger perspective, it's not a durable and reliable solution (1). Also it doesn't directly address the actual source of the problem (2).
Let's look at aspect (1) first:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12206314/detect-if-visual-c-redistributable-for-visual-studio-2012-is-installed
The previous code was following the reference above. But this does not describe the optimal way. 
Depending on Windows Installer and dependencies is not too reliable since the installer keys may change with newer versions.
I don't even know if those keys would be the same when someone includes them into his setup via the merge modules.
To understand this better, there's one thing you need to know:
For the first time, VC libs remain compatible between two versions of Visual Studio
No need to install the VS2015 runtime. The 2017 version will cover both.
(this does not apply to any other two VS versions)
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/porting/binary-compat-2015-2017
With this situation, we don't even know how long this compatibility will be kept. A Visual Studio 2019 could include a new  runtime that is still compatible, but it will be delivered with an installer having all different IDs internally. That's why it's not the best idea to do the detection via installer IDs.
Now I am using the same detection mechanism as the vcredist installer packages themselves:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/ide/deploying-visual-cpp-application-by-using-the-vcpp-redistributable-package
This helps to avoid discrepanices in detection of installation status. (and it is also the MS recommended way).
About the actual problem that this PR didn't address (2):
There's a bug in some of the VS 2017 redist installers in that they are not updating their version information to both registry locations (i.e. x64 and x86), just in one of them (one with WOW6432) and one wihout)
That's why I'm reading both values now and take the higher build number to compare.
Also I changed everything to use the VC 2017 redist.(since it's is just a slightly newer version of the 2015 dlls).. Thanks again for your help and identifying the problem.

A number of users have copied the dlls from a Windows 10 installation.
But there's a better way to get the "right" dlls for the server version:

Locate the installlation source from where you installed Windows Server
If it's an ISO, mount it anywhere
Look for "install.wim" - usually in the "sources" folder
In fact this is just a zip file. Open it with a compression app of your choice
The wim file contains several numbers (e.g. 1,2,3,4) representing different editions of the Os
Check the "windows\system32" folder under each number until you find the files you're looking for and copy them to your Windows Core installation

There may be opportunities for parallelization, but specifically downloading metadata is something that we must not do in parallel. Not even 2 simultaneous workers.
This is due to the fact that web servers are often limiting simultaneous requests, often just to just 2.
Other metadata services have mechanisms to detect excessive downloading which may result in being blocked. For some metadata services, emby has it's own API key, so the worst case could be that a metadata provider would block emby as a whole for all users.
A while ago we already had conversations with metadata providers about the load that emby is causing and we've worked together with another one to change its API in a way that emby can download series data with a single query instead of making single requests for each episode. So that's a real concern.
That's why the described method is not really suitable here.
Parallelization is still a good idea, but it would need to be done in a different way.
We must not parallelise by item but by operation instead. Like one worker scanning the file system, one worker identifying unknown items, one worker downloading metadata from PoividerA, one worker for ProviderB, another worker for downloading images etc.. There's just a handful of "good" metadata sites, adding more does not help here in general.
But metadata providers can be added as plugins now. So, for some special interest areas or coverage of a certain country or language, it might make sense to create a plugin to add a specific provider.
Also it wouldn't help to allow specifying a custom API key because most of those sites will limit requests to 1 or 2 parallel ones by origin - not by API key. If you were thinking that these 2 simultaneous requests would be shared among all emby servers, then you got me wrong. This is not the case.. > Why is it the case, I don't see any feature that would need that ?
Features:
- Remote Control: The server needs to know which devices are online
- Synchronization: Clients apps need to check regularly if there's some content to synchronize

Can we at least have an option to disable that ?

We are supporting Wake-On-LAN for local networks where the server may go to sleep (not just a single HD). Some routers are also available that support this and wake up your machine when a request is received on a certain port.
But Emby is a server application and when it is running it requires unconditional access to the file system. This includes the location of its binaries and all locations containing program data or temporary data. It's an incorrect assumption that it would just be some log entries written that are causing the HDD spin-up. Instead, this would be a neverending story: After preventing log entries being written, we would find out, that Emby is reading from the user database that may cause a file operation, then a client wants to check for new sync items to download, the server needs to update the list of active devices and this needs to be written to disk. Even for unsolicited scanning requests, it is inevitable to perform certain file operations.
To really achieve what you want - "running Emby from memory" - we would need to implement some massive changes that would also introduce a number of other drawbacks.
So bear with me - but your case is pretty exotic and does not justify the effort imo.
I would recommend: Put Emby or its data on an ssd or some usb memory. 
You should also consider: HD spinup and spindown may save energy, but it decreases lifetime and reliability on the other side.
. Implementing push notifications is planned and will arrive soon. 
Regarding sync in general, introducing a configurable check interval would just add another factor of uncertainty to the story, while we're actually aiming to make it even more reliable.
An option that I could imagine instead would be one to fully disable sync for those who don't want or need it. But I'm just chatting here, that would need to be discussed internally.

It seems he's referring to HD spin-up, not machine wakeup from sleep mode.

This is to avoid logging every HTTP request, which wake up the HDD, even when someone unauthorized try to poke my server.

Most likely it won't just be the log messages causing HD spin-up. There are lots of other operations that may cause HD spin-up.
Generally I wouldn't recommend configuring HD spin-down anyway for HDs running server applications. This may cause other (sometimes hard-to-diagnose)  problems as well.
For media content HDs, it may be OK to spin-down, when you don't care about the delay this can cause for playback start.
. What's special about log writing is that it's an operation where any caching is undesired. It is important to have have it written to disk as soon as possible; otherwise it won't be possible to diagnose the preceding operations in case of a crash.

Why don't you simply use the ffmpeg version that is included with the Emby installation package?. On which platform are you?. I'm still curious: On which platform are you? Windows, Linux or else?. I kept the NewSeriesName and NewSeriesYear separate in the API for the following reasons:
- A future implementation (or different client using the API) might want to allow explicit specification of the series folder name. Use cases may be trivial like to have "The Good Wife" instead of "Good Wife" but also language related. A series might have been identified as "Crime Scene Cleaner", but the user wants to use the original name "Der Tatortreiniger"
- IMO an API should provide a reasonable amount of flexibility and not be arbitrarily limited exactly to the use case proposed at the time of creation
If my arguments still didn't convince, I'd like to remark that reducing the signature to nothing but the provider ids would require an additional metadata query at the server, because the current process is like this:
- series = new Series();
- series.Name = request.NewSeriesName;
- series.Path = Path.Combine(request.TargetFolder, seriesFolderName);
- series.ProviderIds = request.NewSeriesProviderIdsDictionary;
- series.RefreshMetadata(refreshOptions, cancellationToken);
So, the name is required before metatada is refreshed.
On the contrary, if we would really pass the provider ids only, there is no 100% guarantee that the query by provider ids will result the exact same item that the user had searched by name in the UI!

. Because those values are immutable and auto-properties are unable to express this.
. No. This restricts access to the setter only, but doesn't make the values immutable.
. Immutability is not a functional requirement. Declaring those fields as readonly may affect the compilation but probably with little to none benefit regarding performance.
The primary reason for declaring those fields as readonly is to improve clarity of code and make it easy to understand.  We could find a number of fancy alternatives, but none of them would meet this requirement any better...
. Well, this just returns all provider ids (= classes implementing IExternalId) that apply to the specific item type (= IExternalId.Supports(item) returns true)
This is the exact same list of ids that are shown in the metadata editor form.
Let's compare the effect of this change to the previous implementation:
1. We are only importing metadata ids that Emby can understand and process for a certain item. (The previous implementation would have imported a "MusicBrainzAlbumId" even for a TV series episode, but there's no reason to import that for a case where the id doesn't apply anyway). I also checked that there is an IExternalId defined for each of the previously hardcoded id strings. (except for TvRage, but that's history)
2. We are now importing ALL provider ids that apply to the specific item, not only the hardcoded ones. (this even includes provider ids specified in plugins)

. Did you include the LiveTV probe in the manual merge? This is important because Emby assumes all live tv is MPEG2 when, at least here in the UK, is often not.
. Where is the existing probe code? 
. The reason why it's causing trouble is probably the same problem fixed by using a small probe size (the override I added).
. How does probing cause that problem? As long as the original stream isn't terminated HDHR tuner locking shouldn't allow that to happen.
. That's not how HDHR tuner locking is supposed to work. HTTP streams only hold a lock as long as they are open, when it closes it frees the tuner. The second request would either take the previous (now free) tuner, or another one if it's free. If probing breaks an existing stream, then the tuner isn't locked. Which means the DVR implementation is flawed (cough MythTV), or there's a bug in SD's code.
If the server is overlapping the probe and request, that might cause failures, but it doesn't sound like that's what's happening.
. Have you escalated it to them?

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14009261/sqlite-accent-insensitive-search
http://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#collation
Resume: using a NOACCENTS collation.
Anyway... the 2 solutions are possible:
1. stop removing diacritics in search field

2. modify the query so SQLITE use COLLATE NOACCENTS

ptr727:
Please see the forum discussion, a couple highlights.
You run a remotely accessible web server, under admin privileges, exposing the system to remote attack.
I understand that you want to install to a location where elevation is not required, and keep your footprint small, and you can self update without needing to elevate. 
But, I think your current design falls short of those objectives, it follows bad security practices and bad Windows deployment practices.
You require elevation during install so the VC redist installer can run, you continue running in that elevated context, and install the bits to disk in that account context, ending up installing in the admin account profile. (Not the first admin account as you state, the account selected by the user that allows admin elevation) You then launch the process, while still in the same elevated context, and end up running in the current user windows session, but under the admin account credentials.
From this point it is impossible for this user to relaunch the app, as the app was actually installed in the admin account, not this account. The web server is now also running with admin privileges, from an admin account. Web server, remotely exploitable, running in an admin account...
To get back your objective:
- Allow installs inside non-admin accounts, if elevation is ever required, drop back to this user context.
- Run the network code with least privileges, certainly not as an admin.
- Install in "%programdata%" for all users or in "%appdata%" for this user.
- Install the VC runtime side-by-side, i.e. copy the DLL's next to your binaries in the install folder, do not run the redist. Pay attention to the VC redist EULA, not all files may be distributed outside of the redist installer. Or link statically to the VC runtime
.

Raithlin:
yonas, Kodi is mainly a front-end - the original concept being that you point it at a hard drive, and it grabs metadata and you play it. Excellent interface, but not as easy to work with when using multiple devices (although this is getting easier with later releases).
Emby is your centralised place for media. From your main server you can connect with almost any device with a client (or the web interface, which is amazing) - even Kodi has a very good add-on. I use Emby to sort and store my media (videos, pics, music, books), and I have Kodi in the living room, and can sync (offline) my phone for videos I want to watch myself, or later (away from my server, for example on a plane).I have friends that use the DLNA component to watch their media using either a PS3, or even DLNA-capable blu-ray players across their local network.
In short, Kodi and Emby work together, not in competition. Emby is quite simply a very capable media server/manager; Kodi an awesome media player.
. Great stuf!! Be sure to follow the instructions at https://emby.media/downloads/emby-for-kodi/  and not simply grab the (old) addon on Kodi, should you choose to go that route. :)

ajbrown:
This is currently an issue for me.  I'm connected to a VPN, and Emby is reporting it's IP address as the VPN's internal IP address.  When my device tries to connect via Emby Connect, it does so using the VPN internal IP address.  Since it's not on the same VPN as Emby, it can't connect.
Obviously this could be fixed by taking the Emby server off the VPN, but for my current setup (with many media-related services running on the same machine) that's not desirable.  If I could force Emby to bind to the LAN interface, that would solve it as well.
This is on Windows.
. From my LAN through the Emby App, it's showing the VPN internal address (172.x.x.x) instead of the LAN address (192.x.x.x).
I don't seem to have the option to override the external address.  I'm on 3.1.11.0
. As a workaround, I shut down the VPN, restarted Emby, then reconnected to the VPN.   It's now reporting the LAN IP for local access.  I'll see how it handles any restarts or reconnects going forward and report back.
It would be nice to be able to force an interface for the advanced users, though.  Even if it's a hidden setting somewhere :-)
. Emby ended up reporting the VPN internal address to Emby Connect after a while. I had to turn off the VPN in order or fix it.
It's definitely an advanced scenario, but seems this would be a problem in any multi network setup.
I guess there are a few options:
- allow secifying the interface to bind to
- allow overriding or preferring the internal address advertised to Emby Connect
- advertise all internal addresses to Emby connect, and update apps so they try the next address if they fail to connect.
If this something I can help with, let me know.

I haven't had a change again.
I can test in a bit by changing the IP again, though.

ppascher:
Hello Luke,
the server is running on CentOS 7. Here is what happened (sorry if I am not explaining it well):
- I had folder "Newshow"
- renamed folder to "newshow" (mv /mnt/freenas/media/videos/tv/Newshow /mnt/freenas/media/videos/tv/newshow" since I was in the process of renaming all my folders to underscore & lowercase
- did a "scan library" in "Manage Server -> Library" to get the changed folder name to register
- checked "Metadata-Manager -> TV -> Newshow" entry
- noticed the "path" entry was still the capitalized "Newshow" but for "Season 1" and each episode underneath had the correct new lowercase folder name "newshow" 
- Symptom was that in the show overview no images were shown (presumably because emby was looking in "Newshow" instead of "newshow"). Season and Episode images were fine.
- Doing a metadata refresh on the show resulted in the show overview images being redownloaded to /mnt/freenas/videos/tv/Newshow (fanart, landscape etc.) as to emby they were missing.
While nothing serious I now had 2 folders where there should only be one. ~~This only happened when the new folder name was the same except for capitalization (So going from 'Newshow' to 'newshow' had this problem while going from "The New Show" to "the_new_show" correctly updated the show's root folder).~~ 
Edit: 
I spoke too soon: I had the same "problem" with other folders where the new folder name had added characters ("My Movie (2008)" -> "my_movie_2008") so capitalization is not the problem it seems. Movies had the old folder recreated and added a .nfo file as well. Manually deleting those again and doing a "scan library" fixed the issue (old folder names are not created anymore) and everything is working fine again. Maybe doing a emby-server restart inbetween helped? Maybe some sort of cache which caused the old folders to be recreated by emby?

. Just to close this down and summarise what has been posted here and what I have deployed and tested.
Sharded folders (referred to here  as complex) only work natively in Emby for movie sources.  Sharded folders do not work and will not ever work for TV sources.
For TV sources each letter shard should be added as a discrete source. 
For example:
using the TV structure from my example zip  you would define each letter folder (e.g. #, A) as a different source.
using the movie structure from my example zip  you would define the base movie folder as a single source and all the shards will be analysed correctly

. Can we extend this ticket to allow defining a different or extra internal address please. When using docker in bridged mode the internal IP is shown as 172...* whilst the clients see the docker host private IP instead which by definition is a different subnet.. I dont profess to fully understand Emby setup in every detail but most home routers dont support split horizon DNS so if you use your WAN DNS address it will resolve to a public IP and not the private one.
Best case scenario this causes all traffic to route into and out of the edge firewall but more likely it just wont work.
I have a working setup here so I dont need support but I would suggest that these settings, especially for new docker users, would benefit for a deeper review, clarification and perhaps simplification.. Is this related to https://github.com/MediaBrowser/Emby/issues/3205 and if so should I close that one with this superseding it?. Is there any progress on this? I cannot see to find a slick way to refresh the data other than renaming a load of folders and then renaming them back (which is way too time consuming and wasteful).
Is there a simpler way I can force Emby en masse to rescan and use the URL only movie.nfo data provided?
It is worth noting that this is made worse by the fact that at some time in the current beta cycle https://github.com/MediaBrowser/Emby/issues/2559 cropped up again (seems fixed now) but it has left me with quite a few bad matches.. Can you suggest any interim way other than manually finding each bad match one by one and manually identifying it (since a fix is not in progress).. Polite re-ask of the above question.
What is the correct way to recover from this bug without obliterating the database to start again and  losing all the watched information etc in the process.
I simply want Emby to refresh all movies but pay attention to the URL only movie.nfo this time.
Edit: still interested in this answer but on closer inspection I see that URL only movie.nfo seems broken again as well. Not always just some times. Is there somewhere we can engage more real time to hammer this out once and for all.. There are two scenarios this now:

The nfo contents are wrong due to human error and when fixed (within the nfo) are not picked up by Emby
Emby ignores the nfo and tags the movie incorrectly (usually bug)

Scenario 1 is rare-ish but human error is human error and there should be a way to recover from it in Emby without having to artificially rename folders on disk to trigger a new movie index.
Ideally these nfo changes should be detected automatically but if it has to be manual I would expect the intuitive way would be for one the Refresh Metadata options to to trigger a new movie index.
Scenario 2 is predominantly driven by bugs in handling URL only movie.nfo and tvshow.nfo. Unfortunately I seem to be the one spotting these and reporting them so I am suffering the most. It was broken and fixed after I reported it (thank you) in last release cycle and it broke and you fixed it during the last beta cycle (without me reporting it). Now I think I have found a one possibly two new test cases  where it doesnt work as expected.
So tl;dr you should be able to force Emby to properly try again to identify something and forget all its previous assumptions without leaving Emby itself.. For what it is worth I have a similar setup but using nginx.

. Yes I have reconfirmed the sample data set provided above generates the same DUPE entries in both Version 3.6.0.84 beta and Version 4.0.0.0 beta. As far as I can tell this is the way it is currently setup, the default and the way it has always been configured here

I am going to guess that since the movie.nfo is a URL type it is using the IMDB ID against OMDB and essentially bypassing TMDB.
. The ttid for the IMDB movie reference
e.g. http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3920266/
Can you replicate the bug with the provided zip file. I have tested it on multiple versions now and had it independently checked as well so I a quite confident it is reproducible with default 4.x install. I think you have found the source of the problem. It appears that in certain rare cases IMDB will end up with duplicates and in even rarer cases the fixed (i.e. merged) entry will take the later ttid rather than the earlier one.
The earlier ttid is then dropped and on the website the now old ttid URL is redirected to the new ttid.
I have found a thread discussing one of the specific examples I happened to hit. https://getsatisfaction.com/imdb/topics/same-title-is-in-the-imdb-database-twice
I think the path of least resistance would be to detect #DUPE# and present the Emby user with some better information.  For example we could name the movie as #DUPE or IMDB ID removed (or similar) and perhaps even insert a fuller explanation as the movie synopsis.
Either way thanks for taking the time to debug this. I will leave this open in case you want to discuss this idea further or if you think it is not worth the effort please feel free to close as resolved.

gerritv:
@LukePulverenti If we can get source for the updater then I am willing to have a go at this. Or some hints on the Setup/Updater flow. Trolling the source tree hasn't provide a way into solving the problem.. I think this is a user error Issue, not a defect/missing functionality.
Looking at the source code, MediaBrowser.ServerApplication:MainStartup.cs checks to see if running as a service as part of its PerformUpdateIfNeeded() code. It would appear that if you are running MB as a service, you should not stop the service prior to doing the update. Updater.exe (which I can't see the source code for??)  is passed the service name to restart after the update completes.
So the solution is: don't stop the service prior to doing an update.
.

As you can see, 
It seems to be a problem due to bad mapping of "Automatic networking". 
Then, when the timeout is over, it tries "connecting without automatic networking", and it works.
Then when i reload the page, the timeout not reappearing for few minutes in (just 1-2 minutes, then it reappear, etc.).
I've also see that the url https://emby.sky-fvt.com/emby/system/info/public it's not reachable by my web browser in first time (when timeout appear), 
but when the emby web client has loaded the login page successfully, then the info pages are displaying correctly in my browser.
With direct connection to http://localIP:8096 or https://localIP:8920, the problem is the same.
Emby version :  3.0.5972.0
Mono Version : 4.2.3.4-0xamarin2

.
tylerapplebaum:
Ok, thanks. I ended up having to reassign the permissions on the user account in order for them to view the libraries they previously had permission to view.
. Since the update to 3.1.2, mine now looks like your screenshot. Prior to that, I had a very quick timeout and it looked like my original screenshot.
Since the update fixed my issue, I'll go ahead and close this..

SludgeVohaul:
Same for photo metadata in the DB (TypedBaseItems.data DateModified) - the imported photo's EXIF DateTime tag is converted to UTC based on the server's location.
As the EXIF specification does not define any timezone information, I think the timestamp should not be modified, or the UTC should be based on the timezone computed from the eventually present Lat/Long data (and  don't forget the eventual daylight saving time). 
After all this has been done, one finally could admire the beautiful sunrise picture taken at 23:00:00 UTC...

marmay:
Regarding the scaling, I made some fundamental assumptions in the code:
- state.VideoStream.Width and state.VideoStream.Height contain the actual resolution of the video stream, so the values are not rounded to some resolutions that makes sense (e.g. 1920x1080) and do not take the aspect ratio into account.
- The display aspect ratio is passed through into the output container.
I do not know, whether those assumptions are correct. If they are not, then my code most likely breaks stuff.
If those assumptions are correct, however, I think it should do the right thing, which in my opinion is: If the requested output size or a maximum size are set, then set the output size to min( requested output size, maximum size ). If those values are different from the input size, add a scaling filter. One could argue, whether it would be better to set the output size to min( input size, requested output size, maximum size ), i.e. server does downsampling, but clients do the upsampling.
. Sounds reasonable. I can isolate the changes and rebase the commit, if you want to?
I'll also do some more testing regarding anamorphic pixels.
. The field is mandatory, but I think that :0 is a sane default value, but I did most testing with /dev/dri/renderD128.
According to ffmpeg documentation, this is the render node that is used for hardware acceleration. For dual video card systems, it may make sense to use :1 or something else instead.
I think /dev/dri/renderD128 depends on the precise hardware that is used, i.e. I found /dev/dri/renderD64 as well, but :0 should be fairly portable.
. Ah, sorry, I misread the documentation.
:0 refers to the display, i.e. if the server runs without an X server, then this does not work.
/dev/dri/card0 seems to be the best default value.
Btw, thanks for making this such a nice experience. I hope I'll find some time for more pull requests that are not as much work for you as this one. :-)

hatharry:
When emby is started it checks to see if Service Control (sc.exe) can be executed by the current service user and has the correct permissions to query the service. When this is true the restart button appears in the web UI, as we know the service user can restart the service using Service Control (sc.exe).
On restart the app is disposed then Service Control (sc.exe) is executed by cmd to stop and start the service.
. The "Emby.Service.exe" executable launches Emby server as its own task/thread. This causes the service to enter the "started" state as fast as possible.
The executable also restarts the server process without restarting the service. This is achieved by reading the exit code from the server process. Restarting the process if necessary. 
Automatic Updates also work due to the updater being able to start the service. On service stop the process is also stopped. 
The Emby server itself has two options added "-norestart" which causes Emby to exit with a code instead of restarting. and "-notray" which removes the tray icon because it is not needed when running as a service..

bsdfirst:
I've had a dig around.  It appears to be a compile time option.  ffmpeg is either linked against an 8bit OR a 10bit libx264.  I can't see a way to force 8bit h264 when compiled against the 10bit library (which is the default in Arch).
Basically, the whole thing is getting forced to 10bit (despite the high profile being 8-bit) because of this:
Incompatible pixel format 'yuv420p' for codec 'libx264', auto-selecting format 'yuv420p10le'
We are already specifying -pix_fmt yuv420p but the libx264 codec is forcing a switch to the yuv420p10le colour space.  Which then causes and error because the high profile is also forced on the commandline.
One solution could be to abstract the -profile parameter to allow the user to choose between high and high10 in the config?  That may not be desirable though - I'm pretty new to Emby (okay...2 days now) but the philosophy seems to be "just work" without exposing lots of complex options to the user.
I'll keep looking, but at the moment I don't see another obvious solution that won't break things as people shift to libx264-10bit.  (Short of shipping a statically compiled ffmpeg as part of the build.)
. Yeah.  Being able to change the path to ffmpeg would solve the problem for advanced users (and those are going to be the users that have managed to install the 10bit version of libx264).  I suspect the problem will crop up again as the 10bit version of the library starts to become the default across other distros.
I don't think there is a single easy answer.  On a positive note however, I have replaced the libx264-10bit package with the libx264 package.  It satisfies the same packaging depend for ffmpeg and installs the same library in the same location - so it's all good from a linking perspective.
I've only tested on the commandline not in Emby proper, but that certainly seems to work.  So perhaps the short term answer is to check the libx264 version as part of your ffmpeg validation?
. ffmpeg-enconders-8bit.txt
ffmpeg-enconders-10bit.txt
. Identical if you were hoping to use that for detection...

solabc16:
Hello
Thanks for the comments, perhaps a litttle more is needed in terms of explanation and clarification, so let me address that.


Yes, it compliles with both the NETSTANDARD1_6 and NET46 defines.


The only additional reference is to System.Xml, which is fully supported on core: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/api/system.xml#System_Xml


We are not manually appending to any existing log, the logging function for developing/troubleshooting the log manager (NlogManager) itself is through necessity entirely standalone.


The method call for this logging has a conditional attribute defined, so unless the library is built with DEBUG defined, all code related to this functionality effectively does not exist. This is the normal case for any beta/stable builds currently being published. (see documentation comments in the code for more details)


With regard to reading the value of EnableDebugLevelLogging,  we are using XPath navigation to query information in the DOM, so this is not as crude as attempting to manipulate the file as raw text.


The approach above was deemed to be the most sensible answer to the question "how do we get early access to the system configured value of this setting, without adding unnecessary complexity to either the library itself or its caller?" (i.e. adding dependencies on configuration managers)


The worst outcome with respect to the above is that for some reason in the future the location of this configuration setting changes, which would result in the initial severity defaulting to Info, which intentionally represents no change to the existing behaviour.


As this kind of change would be considered unlikely and unnecessary, it wasn't a convincing argument to overcomplicate the implementation.


All changes have been implemented in such a way that the existing implementation and behaviour remain unchanged, whilst any calls to leverage the new functionality are by default fail safe and unable to introduce new or unexpected exceptions.


James
. As a further update, to gain some confidence in the changes and get some real-world feedback, I've created a customised build of 3.1.235-beta for Synology/XPEnology.
This includes this PR and a tweaked version of MediaBrowser.Server.Mono.exe, the changes to MediaBrowser.Server.Mono.exe are straightforward in nature and detailed below for reference.
```
//
// Use new Constructor and ReloadLogger method available in PR #2304, which
// enables custom filters to be applied to the log and uses the configured
// LogSeverity level from initial startup, rather than switching back to Info
// until the configuration settings are read.
//
// var logManager = new NlogManager(appPaths.LogDirectoryPath, "server");
// logManager.ReloadLogger(LogSeverity.Info);
var logManager = new NlogManager(appPaths.LogDirectoryPath, "server", appPaths.ConfigurationDirectoryPath);
logManager.ReloadLogger();
```
The Emby Server log output shows that this has resolved the issue of Debug messages being lost during application start-up.; on a normal build, the first three messages do not appear in the log.

James. Hello @SvenVandenbrande - today's commits were to get the latest beta built on VS2017 using the MediaBrowser solution instead of the MediaBrowser.Mono solution. This was for Synology/XPEnology - i.e. a Mono target.
. Hello
Thanks for the patch Ivan-L.
Luke, what's the thinking behind persisting this to disk in the first place?
The data is volatile and is only useful during the lifetime of the Emby Server process.
There is perhaps an argument that it is useful should the lookup fail on first run and there is no address cached (persisted to disk), but on the flip side this just raises the possibility of using a wrong address for the initial timer interval.
Perhaps a faster retry mechanism on failure (i.e. dynamically reduce the timer interval) would be an alternate and more effective approach, as the failure is likely to resolve itself. If the device does not have a functioning Internet connection, then the point is moot anyway.
Best
- James

enilfodne:
Thanks for the quick fix, I've noticed however that Emby does not properly parse idx files.
An idx file may contain multiple languages, however Emby does not properly index multiple languages and shows Unknown Language for every idx/sub file. Meaning it doesn't properly parse the language code as well.
For example, excerpt from an idx file with multiple languages defined:
id: en, index: 0
timestamp: 00:00:0x:xxx, filepos: 000000000
...
id: fr, index: 1
timestamp: 00:00:0x:xxx, filepos: 000000000
...
id: es, index: 2
timestamp: 00:00:0x:xxx, filepos: 000000000
In the example above, the idx file contains the reference to 3 languages (en, fr, es) and the respective position in the sub file.
The language can be changed by tweaking the overlay:
-filter_complex "[1:x]scale=res_w:res_y[sub] ; [0:0] [sub] overlay
x is the language index as extracted from the idx file.

animosity22:
Why not just not use the /emby at all and just use a virtualhost in Apache with something like emby.media.app?
I use 1 A Record and 2 CNAME DNS entries to map to my DDNS for my apache proxy at home.
I have mappings for:
apps.media.apps
ombi.media.apps
emby.media.apps
I like using default with no path appended for the stuff that I have other folks use and all my apps (Sonarr/NZBGet/Radarr/etc) all use additional paths.
I use 3 certbots to autorenew the certs as well so it's pretty smooth. I tend to try to make things as simple for the folks using my stuff as possible.. I've never used caddy but from a few searches, I'm not sure why you want to use /emby to append to the end.
Just map the root to the domain:
emby.domain.com
There is a pretty good link here that goes through the same concepts I use on apache on caddy. With custom DNS records, it makes it simple and avoids a lot of the overhead.
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BzPd75yQAJYhWG1keDJpWU9QZVU/view. Is there a reason you want to have double authentication via Basic Auth and Emby Auth? Seems like you are over complicating the approach.
Basic Auth is also kind old. You can flip over to forms based auth pretty easily as I did that for my home connection.
I just use a separate domain based virtual host for my emby server and let that through by itself.. If you hit the home button and the lock button on the side (iphone 7), it records a screenshot..

Criena:
Ah, my bad. I scimmed through the issues, but only checking for "^feature". Considering there are quite a few people interested in this, I wonder why nothing is happening since 2015.. Basic Auth might be old, but it's also much more secure than advertising Web applications publicly.
If Emby has a security flaw, only internal users will be able to exploit it. Everyone else won't even get access to any part of Emby.. I'm currently doing that with an nginx in front of Emby. The downside is that the app doesn't support this and is therefore unusable if being outside the internal network. But for that I'm using the normal web interface.
Would it be really such an issue to take the login credentials from an HTTP-Auth header opposed to from the current login form?. I don't see an issue with Emby requiring a user. Currently Emby takes the login credentials from the login form (username and password). If Emby would check whether an "Authorization" header was sent by the client (in my instance the reverse proxy, nginx) and use these credentials opposed to showing a login form, it should be fine. Emby then still has its user that it can base everything on. Just instead of using an HTML form to provide the username, it would come from HTTP header. The reverse proxy (in my instance nginx) can forward the authentication information to the Emby server. I'm doing this with other servers as well.
. Just to make sure there is no misunderstanding... This approach means that the user who is logging in via HTTP Basic Auth would need to exist with Emby already in order for the mapping to work. It's just an alternative to the HTML login form.
Independent from that it might be interesting to get an LDAP integration for the backend, but that's a separate topic..

Looking at the error message and comparing the two requests, the problem is most likely the empty xmlns:u attribute for u:AddPortMapping. The SOAPACTION is also missing the xmlns details.
(NOTE: If you have noticed that each of these requests is to a different router, you are correct. Emby did not contact the correct router - It sent the request to a second router that extends the wireless network with WDS, a TP-Link Archer C2, to which my PC is now connected. However, this is a recent change in my networking setup, long after I first opened this issue. Therefore, that can be ignored for now, but this means that the UPnP issue most likely affects all TP-Link routers.). Have you seen my edit to my previous comment?
 Anyway, here is the XML: https://pastebin.com/ce2HbBFE
In addition to the edit above, the request URL from Emby may be incorrect. Original setup was to connect to the main router (TD-W9980 at 192.168.1.1) directly over Wi-Fi.
