dominic-p:
Wow, thanks for the quick and insightful reply. I'm still pretty new to service workers. Could they be used to send an event or message to the main thread that's handling playback to start the next song? I could see it working like this:

Song starts.
A message is sent to the service worker to schedule a message/notification for when the song ends (based on song length)
Song ends. The service worker sends a message to the main app to start the next song.

Of course, if the user intervened in playback, any pending messages would have to be canceled.
Thoughts? Bad idea?. Ok, I'll look into the service worker API when I get some time.
I know there's also a Wake Lock API that the W3C is playing with. If that gets supported, we might be able to simply acquire a CPU only wake lock when playback starts and release it when playback stops.. Makes sense. I've been exploring a few different avenues that could work.


ExtendableEvent.waitUntil() could be perfect, but I'm not sure how to make it work. See this discussion.


The W3C Task Scheduler API should also be able to solve the problem if it's ever adopted. Same with the W3C Wake Lock API. I think the later is implemented behind an experimental flag in Chrome for desktop, but I'm not sure about mobile (where we need it).


The most promising solution I found that could work now is to leverage the Push API. Basically, when the user starts playing a song, a message is sent to the server with the song's duration. Then, the server sends a push message to the client just before the song is set to end. Ideally, this would wake the client and allow it play the next song. There are 2 unresolved issues with this approach I can see so far: 1) I'm not sure if the push would actually wake the device or if it would just be queued for when the device wakes up (defeating the point). 2) I'm not sure if we can send a push message without a visible UI (which would annoy users).


Anyway, I wanted to document what I found for now. If I have time to play with it some more I'll post here. But, we can leave the issue closed until we have something concrete/usable.. You may be right about that, but from what I've been reading, Service Workers are meant to be short lived. It would probably change their life-cycle/design philosophy considerably to enable playback. But, we'll just have to see how the landscape develops.. Sorry to post again on a closed issue. I had one other idea that could work. What if we live streamed the audio?
The server could dynamically generate a stream from the files in the playlist. We wouldn't have to worry about js being suspended because the audio source wouldn't need to be changed. 
There are other advantages too including faster startup time and the ability to do fancy adaptive bitrate streaming if the bandwidth changes. 
There seem to be quite a few different streaming protocols out there including the Web Audio API. This node package looks like an interesting take on the problem using Web Audio over Web Sockets. 
Thoughts?.

Mediainfo does report the 10bit encoding in the log:
"PixelFormat":"yuv420p10le"
Anything over yuv420p, should be transcoded with FireTV stick (Gen2).  Although further testing might be warranted.
hevc_10bit_fireTV_stick_gen2_log.txt
This issue really only applies to the FireTV stick Gen2 model.. As the old fireTV stick did not support HEVC natively , and the FireTV boxes already support 10Bit HEVC..
The Gen2 Stick uses the Mali-450 GPU,  Mali-T800 GPU is required for 10-bit color depth.  So this is a hard limitation on this stick.. Lost access to FireTV stick Gen2 at this time.  I will re-open when I have access to another Gen2 stick, and am able to supply logs for this issue. . server-63640669405.txt

ExecStart=/usr/bin/emby-server. Apparently the dotnet runtime expects curl to be built with openssl instead of gnutls, and I'm using the latter, that's why it's not happy. I guess I have no choice but to switch to openssl :(. Had time to try on the rpi 3, building curl against openssl instead of gnutls didn't help. I'll need to look further into it.. Ok, I get it now. The dotnet runtime expects curl abi 3, not abi 4 on armhf. I'll have to either disable versioned symbols, which I'd prefer but expect not to work, or ship a very old curl version, which contains all those nice vulnerabilities: https://curl.haxx.se/docs/vuln-7.15.5.html. Found a better way, rpmbuild can be overriden to ignore certain false positives regarding dependencies. The next beta and stable arm releases will install without complaining about this.. The rpm doesn't come from a repository so you need to download it and install it manually.. You're not looking at the right Dockerfile, we're not using any Debian-based distros as our base image.
I've added iconv support to our ffmpeg build, could you please give the latest beta docker image a try?. While the arm CPUs from Marvell are indeed armhf capable, the WD firmware is armel and won't run armhf code. Did you try running your package on any of the arm models?. Docker images ship their own implementation of the C stdlib (glibc, musl, uclibc or whatever the case may be) and dynamic linker, which is why they can (in theory, because the linux kernel does not use hardware floating point, but not always true) run armhf code even if the host is armel, provided the CPU does have a VFP unit. Our deb packages don't ship the C stlib and use the system one instead, everything inside uses the armhf dynamic linker (ld-linux-armhf.so.3) while the WD firmware has the armel dynamic linker (ld-linux.so.3).. Possibly, but that's where the in theory comes in, I already tried on my EX2 Ultra to no avail, the dotnet runtime refused to work even with the right dynamic linker. I should give docker another try though, it's way easier to do the testing with it.. Now that I know there are x64 models, I tried adding wd packages to our builds, but I don't have any x64 wd device at hand. Would you be willing to give them a try?. FTR, the Arch Linux package uses skia-sharp60 (not skia-sharp), which is at 1.60.0, the logs should display that version during startup. I refreshed the metadata and it works now.. I got tired of killing the processes myself every time. Due to this I wrote a tiny bash script that checks every 5 seconds if more then one process of ffmpeg is running and then kill the older process.
```bash
!/usr/bin/bash
replace with your ffmpeg executable path
ffmpeg_path="/usr/bin/ffmpeg"
while [ true ]; do
        amount=$(( $(ps aux | grep $ffmpeg_path | wc -l) - 1))
        if [ $amount -gt 1 ]; then
                pkill --oldest ffmpeg
        fi
        sleep 5
done
```
Run this script on your server in background.

src: local('Material Icons'), local('MaterialIcons-Regular'), url(2fcryfnatjcs6g4u3t-y5zjzjt5fdej140u2djyc3my.woff2) format('woff2'), url(2fcryfnatjcs6g4u3t-y5ewrjpiaoeww8aihgqwrjao.woff) format('woff')


Any hints to a way I can confirm these fonts are being loaded correctly ?
Edit: I found the problem!!! 
Had nothing to do with Emby, actually. 
After checking in Chrome Dev Tools i found the material font file was not being downloaded from the network I decided to check the rendered font for the icons and discovered the icons were being rendered with the Noto Sans font in my local files instead of the Material Icon font.  
Them it all clicked: I had installed this font in my computer in the weekend and added some shady stuff to /etc/fonts/local.conf following these steps. So I just reverted these changes and everything came back to normal.
Im curious to undestand how this happened since it happened only in Chrome and only in the Emby webUI. No other websites were affected afaik. (maybe there is a way to force the Emby webUI to use the material icon font??)
Anyway, thanks for you help, Luke. I really appreciate the job you are doing with Emby. Thats exactly what I did to figure out the font was not being downloaded. No HTTP requests were being made when I was having this problem. As soon as I got rid of the /etc/fonts/local.conf file the HTTP requests to download the font started to show up in the network tab.
I might be wrong, but I think Chrome tried to check if the material font was my local filesystem prior to requesting it from the network, then Fontconfig recieved this request, checked   /etc/fonts/local.conf to see if it was available and matched the requested font with Noto Sans, returning Noto Sans font to Chrome use to render the fonts that were supposed to be Material. 
Only speculation from what I briefly read here and here, but I will take some time later today to look into that again.
Problem is solved, so feel free to close the issue, Luke. Thanks for your help.

Ayrler:
But If I do so I end up getting content that can't be identified either manually or automatically. Half of my content is just raw content without metadata. It seems that an unset library does not support the same TV/Movie naming as specific libraries. 
E.g : 

Those are basically the only available options, and the structure is:
\Detroit Metal City
     \[Anime]Detroit_Metal_City_01[720p].mp4
The exact same structure is recognized using TV content type but not the unset one. And that's why I was fiddling around with the TV library to at least use its metadata. 
Edit: After testing a couple of possibilities, it seems that the season number must be declared in both episodes and the season folder (which somehow is not a necessity when using the TV content type).
But when the name of the global show doesn't match the name of the season it identifies only the season. 
E.g : 
\D Gray-man (not identified and cannot be manually identified)
     \D.Gray-man.Hallow.S01 (identified)
          \D.Gray-man.Hallow.S01E01.mp4 (identified)
That's because D Gray-man and D Gray-man Hallow have different sheets on TVDB.
I think that this issue can be resolved if the unset content type had same identification process as the TV one. 
It goes without saying that for anime, this scenario happens very often where the name of the show is not exactly the same for each season and seasons are not necessarily related to each other (OAV/Spin-offs/Specials...)..

Thanks for the tag @LukePulverenti , I think it would be more accurate to call this a Bug report however, the missing settings menu when streaming from a synced source breaks two other features in addition to the quality selection feature.
It's true that I wrote this in the style of an enhancement request, but that was only because this is the first and only version of Emby I've used, so I was uncertain what the intended, or proper functionality of the quality selection in this use case should be, so I instead documented how I'd expect this feature to function normally.. It actually looks like spacebar maps to whatever the previous button that was clicked in the web ui. 
So if you click the fullscreen button, then press space, it'll exit fullscreen, click space again and it'll go fullscreen again.
To replicate space going back, all you should have to do is click the back button once, then space will continue to go back until you click another button in the UI.
This is the behavior I observed under Mac OS, Chrome 62, Emby 3.2.40.0. > Is there a good place where I can find info about developing a plugin?
The wiki has decent documentation on plugin development. Check out the getting started page, and read the rest of the wiki. 
Your C# knowledge won't be of much use, the language used by Emby is .NET and Mono.
If you're looking for more concrete examples, I found digging through the GameBrowser Plugin source useful. I believe it also defines additional metadata sources (for games) so you might be able to use it for reference.
As for the overall points regarding Metadata managing, there's definitely work that needs to be done, seasons of shows stored in different directories particularly struggle for example, the solution really shouldn't be just to rework your directory structures..

ocal/bin/ffprobe -programdata ${emby_server_data_dir} -os freebsd"

I also plan on replacing the binary blobs with libraries which re-implement class members, but just throw not implemented exceptions i.e. they will become dummy libraries; I'll be doing this purely to satisfy build time dependencies.
One thing I noticed when working on this is that your .net core releases are based around a small app host library called 'EmbyServer' , this does not appear to be published in this repository. I am re-implementing parts of this myself by examining it's members using Visual Studio; I have excluded this re-implementation from my repository for reasons I'll go into further down.
Since the final build will include dummy libraries instead of your proprietary ones, the server wont run as is. Therefore I plan on implementing a function within my version of 'EmbyServer' to download the proprietary ones on first run and replace the dummy libraries with those.

2) It'll be build-able on .net core.

MYDIH:
This was actually the result of a bad mergerfs configuration.. Dumb me, I didn't noticed it before, but actually it's even broader than that, just take any avi file, giving it an mp4 extension (instead of avi). ffmpeg is smart enough to ignore the extension and auto detect the avi container, but it will not do it if the -f mp4 option is passed.
You can test this using one of the Big Buck Bunny dist files : http://bbb3d.renderfarming.net/download.html
I can guess then that my seeking problem isn't related to this issue, I will investigate further and raise a  new issue when I stumble upon it again.. cayars:
Why would you want to have to double up your media having it in two or more places?  You could symlink the same file to multiple places.
Would it not be better to have a default audio language that is always used if present in the file regardless of the "default" track?
If done this way you could still have two movies libraries that you manually track/update either using symlinks or just copying the file.
What are we missing?. When we say "default" we're talking about in the file itself not in Emby.. You're not following the naming conventions used for the paths so that is most likely why you are getting weird results.
You want to have:
/TV Shows/Matt Houston (1982)/
/TV Shows/Matt Houston (1982)/Season 0
   all season 0 files here
/TV Shows/Matt Houston (1982)/Season 1
   all season 1 files here
/TV Shows/Matt Houston (1982)/Season 2
   all season 2 files here
/TV Shows/Matt Houston (1982)/Season 3
   all season 3 files here
There is slight differences in how you can setup you libs but this has always worked perfectly for me on Emby, Plex and Kodi.
Carlo

smoebody:
@anoma until this is addressed you can use this workaround:
In Expert->Advanced->Bind to local network address you can insert the IP of your Docker-Host. Next you have to bind the http-port e.g. -p 8096:8096. This changes the LAN access url to \<Docker-Host-IP>:8096 and should therefore be accessable by Chromecast. It doesn't matter to emby that the IP is not available on any interface within the container. It just binds to the available. But the provided IP is used to publish the LAN address to chromecast and other clients i guess. .

OK so I was a little bored today. and I started mapping out the JSON structure from the API and this is what I have come up with thus far.
I set it up as explained above. I have not yet added any examples of use for anything.
before each element name I have placed the conditions that have to be met before that element will be returned. If there is a Type= in the condition this simply means this is the media type(s) you need to query for whether it be an enumeration request or a direct request. if you need to supply a field name in the Fields parameter as wee that is also noted in it. If there are any other conditions they have to be fulfilled as well. I did fond out that the API for the most part is set up so that if an object does not exist for that element it will not add the element to the returned data. There are exceptions to this but not many and those will return a null if the object does not exist. I also included the data type for the object that is returned for that element. The structure will be exactly as you see it. the nesting specifically. If you do not meet the conditions of an element that element will not be in the returned JSON data structure.
Enumerations are pretty much the same thing as this whole structure with a condensed amount of information in it and there can be multiple structures in an enumeration array.
This is still not complete and I am continuing to read through the code to try and locate more elements that need to be added. If there is something missing and or incorrect please let me know. I am not all that proficient in c#, but I'm learning.

      (Type=Episode) 'IndexNumberEnd': int(),
      (Type=Episode) 'SeriesName': str(),
      (Type=Episode and Fields=SpecialEpisodeNumbers) 'AirsAfterSeasonNumber': int(),
      (Type=Episode and Fields=SpecialEpisodeNumbers) 'AirsBeforeEpisodeNumber': int(),
      (Type=Episode and Fields=SpecialEpisodeNumbers) 'AirsBeforeSeasonNumber': int(),
      (Type=Episode and SeasonId) 'SeasonId': str(),
      (Type=Episode. Season) 'SeasonName': str(),
      (Type=Episode, Season and SeriesId) 'SeriesId': str(),
      (Type=Episode, Season and Series) 'SeriesPrimaryImageTag': str(),
      (Type=Episode, Season and Fields=SeriesStudio and Series) 'SeriesStudio': str(),
      (Type=Series) 'AirDays': array([int(0=Sunday, 1=Monday, 2=Tuesday, 3=Wednesday, 4=Thursday, 5=Friday, 6=Saturday)])
      (Type=Series) 'AirTime': str()
      (Type=Series) 'Status': str()
    }

. I figured it was from an API change. to keep it more in form with the API should there be a Fields argument addition to include GenreItems that would return just the GenreItems? The same thing would also apply to any other changes of the like. To keep it in form with the API? because of how the API works where it will not return that fields if there is no contents to that field one could interpret the field not being there as there is no data. instead of it being thought of as an incorrect field name. the API does not bump back an error if a field is included that does not exist, and or the conditions have not been met to be able to return data. It simply does not return it. 
Due to the documentation not containing all of the available API commands and what conditions have to be met to get specific pieces of data returned it can leave someone guessing. 
I do not know if you get where I am coming from with this. It can draw a big question mark as to whether or not a call is correct or if there is simply no data to be returned. 
This is a hard thing to deal with at this stage in the development of Emby because it can breaks apps that currently use the API but may not have a call correct if you all of a sudden start throwing errors for an improper call. or if you change the API to return a value of NULL if there is no data to be had. So getting together a complete list of every parameter/condition for each data set and making it available I think would be the best solution. it doesn't have to be a full on write up of each and every single bit. something like what i have outlined above would be sufficient i think. But also explain the fact that if there is no data for that field item it will not be returned. and if there is an improper field item it will react in the same manner.
I sat there scratching my head wondering as to why when i was using the API and not getting the data returned and in the web front end it was showing the data that i was trying to get. LOL Then for hoots and ha ha's i decided to use Genres instead of GenreItems. I had gotten the GenreItems data set name from reading one of the other API connectors code. .

Hi, I don't know what is the logic behind it since i have old movies which this issue doesn't happen (TMDB ID is empty or with a valid ID) and i have recently added movies (past 2-3 weeks) which has '0' (Zero) in the TMDB ID section (and NFO) and vice versa (old with zero and new with empty/valid id).
So the answer is yes new added movies get's TMDB ID zero but not all of them, and i don't know on what condition this happen.. That's integrating havn't thought about it.. It's possible since i had other app for metadata...
I now did the following:

On the newest movie I have added: I've check the movie directory - All files where owned by emby user and group except the .mkv and .nfo which where owned by root user. But this movie did not have this problem, It had a tmdb ID (as opposed to empty/zero ID where other providers ID are found). So that's not a good movie example but looks like you are right that other apps may add the .nfo data...
I've located the next newest movie added that DID had <tmdbid>0</tmdbid> in it's NFO file (The movie added Jan  4 "Jarhead (2005)"). This time all files in the movie directory were owned by emby user and group (including .mkv and .nfo files).
I've deleted the NFO file and immediately refreshed metadata from the UI with replace all metadata option on this movie. 
In the new NFO file (verified by 'create time') there was still  <tmdbid>0</tmdbid> section in it. 

I hope that's help. Let me know if i can add more information. . Ok I identify manually 160 items (took a while) and confirmed that the issue cannot reproduce. I suspect (like you suggested) that this happened due to a combination of 1. Another app adding NFO files and 2. Filesystem level permissions that denied emby user access.
Thanks!.

My solution to this is to mount a Samba/AFP network share using GVFS on linux as a virtual file system.
I did some tests and it works perfectly.
GVFS may be a built-in feature on some linux distributions. My OS is ubuntu 18.04.
Steps

Prepare smb credentials file smb.key which contains
username
WORKGROUP
password
Mount SMB share as GVFS volume
replace SMB_HOSTNAME and SHARE_NAME with your info
shell
gio mount 'smb://SMB_HOSTNAME/SHARE_NAME' < smb.key
Create a symlink of this volume to your Emby library path
UID is your current linux user id. Emby should have permissions on this volume.
shell
ln -s '/run/user/UID/gvfs/smb-share:server=SMB_HOSTNAME,share=SHARE_NAME' /path/to/your/emby/library

Notes:
1. SMB storage server can running on linux; it is not limited to Windows only.
2. The network connection between SMB server and Emby should be good enough. I suggest to put these VPSs on LAN at same region, eg. Virtual Private Cloud.
. These subtitles are downloaded from the internet, some translation team will insert some extra information such as team member info and some ads at the beginning of SRT file. However, the time of this extra info does not start at 00:00, which cause this ordering problem.
I solved this by writing a python script to preprocess these files manually,  but I think it would be better if this procedure can be done by Emby.
Maybe this feature can be implemented as an advanced option in subtitle menu? So users are able to choose whether to do the preprocessing..
